By doing so, we're not only improving our physical and mental health, but also increasing our productivity, confidence, and overall quality of life. This can be achieved through simple yet effective means such as regular exercise, healthy eating, and adequate sleep. Additionally, investing in personal development through education and self-care activities can also have a profound impact on our lives. By spending wisely on ourselves, we're making a long-term investment in our happiness and success.

I prefer working in the office because it provides a structured and organized environment that helps me stay focused and productive. Unlike working from home, where distractions are abundant, the office setting allows me to separate my personal and professional life. Additionally, being around colleagues and supervisors encourages collaboration, creativity, and accountability. The office also offers access to necessary resources and equipment, making it easier to complete tasks efficiently. Overall, the office setting helps me to stay motivated and achieve my goals, making it my preferred workspace.

As a child, I spent hours glued to the TV, mesmerized by documentaries showcasing exotic landscapes and vibrant cultures. The Travel Channel was my favorite, and I would imagine myself exploring the ancient ruins of Machu Picchu or island-hopping in Greece. These shows sparked a curiosity in me, and I began to dream of experiencing the world beyond my hometown. As I grew older, my fascination with TV-inspired travel only intensified, and I started saving up for my own adventures. Now, I've visited over 10 countries, and I attribute it all to the window to the world that TV provided.

Being a good friend requires more than just being present; it demands an open mind. When we approach relationships with a closed mind, we limit our ability to understand and empathize with others. An open mind allows us to listen actively, consider different perspectives, and avoid judgment. This fosters a safe and supportive environment where friends feel comfortable sharing their thoughts and feelings. By embracing the power of an open mind, we can build stronger, more meaningful relationships and become better friends. This mindset encourages personal growth, tolerance, and acceptance, ultimately leading to more fulfilling and lasting friendships.

The joy of unplanned travel lies in its ability to surprise and delight. Without the constraints of a rigid itinerary, travelers can stumble upon hidden gems and unexpected experiences that become the most memorable moments of their trip. By embracing the unknown, travelers can tap into the local culture and gain authentic insights into the community. A wrong turn can lead to a secluded beach, a chance encounter can result in a home-cooked meal, and a spontaneous decision can lead to a thrilling adventure. Unplanned travel is not about the destination, but about the journey, and the surprises that await along the way.

Drama movies have a profound impact on me, evoking emotions and sparking introspection. I find myself drawn to the complexities of human relationships, the struggles, and the triumphs. These films offer a window into the human experience, allowing me to connect with characters on a deeper level. The authenticity of drama movies resonates with me, as they often tackle real-life issues and explore the nuances of the human condition. By immersing myself in these stories, I gain a deeper understanding of myself and the world around me, fostering empathy and self-awareness. This emotional connection is what captivates me, making drama movies an integral part of my cinematic journey.

Financial freedom is the cornerstone of achieving my goals. Without it, I'm trapped in a cycle of financial stress, constantly worrying about making ends meet. This mental burden leaves me drained, with no energy to pursue my passions. With financial freedom, I can focus on my objectives, unencumbered by the weight of debt and financial anxiety. I'll have the resources to invest in myself, take calculated risks, and make meaningful progress towards my aspirations. Only then can I truly relax, knowing that I'm in control of my financial destiny and on track to achieving my dreams.

As a child, I was fascinated by the way things worked. I would spend hours disassembling and reassembling toys, curious about the intricate mechanisms behind them. This curiosity sparked a passion within me, and I knew I wanted to become an engineer. Through hard work and dedication, I pursued my dream, exceling in math and science classes. I participated in robotics competitions, interned at engineering firms, and sought guidance from professionals in the field. With each step, my passion grew, and I became more determined to turn my dream into a reality. Now, I'm one step closer to making it happen.

Television has been a significant part of my life since childhood. It has not only been a source of entertainment but also a window to the world, exposing me to diverse cultures, lifestyles, and perspectives. Through TV, I have learned about historical events, geographical locations, and social issues, broadening my knowledge and understanding of the world. Moreover, TV has been a reliable companion during stressful times, providing a much-needed escape from reality and relaxation. My favorite shows and movies have helped me unwind and recharge, making TV an indispensable part of my daily routine.

My cozy study room is a tranquil oasis where I escape the chaos of the world and delve into the realm of knowledge. Soft, golden lighting and plush carpeting create a warm ambiance, making me feel snug and focused. The walls are adorned with inspirational quotes and vibrant artwork, sparking creativity and motivation. My study room is a haven where I can immerse myself in books, explore new ideas, and chase my dreams, free from distractions and interruptions.

I have always been an avid enthusiast of physical activity, and over the years, I have come to realize that I prefer team sports over exercising alone. The primary reason for this preference is the sense of camaraderie and accountability that comes with being part of a team. When I'm playing a team sport, I feel motivated to push myself harder and perform better, knowing that my teammates are relying on me. Additionally, team sports provide an opportunity to socialize and make new friends, which is not possible when exercising alone. Furthermore, team sports often involve strategic planning and coordination, which helps to improve my communication and problem-solving skills. Overall, I find that team sports offer a more engaging and rewarding experience than exercising alone.

Studying with others in a traditional classroom setting has numerous benefits. For one, it fosters social interaction, which is essential for building relationships and networking opportunities. Additionally, being surrounded by peers motivates students to stay engaged and focused, leading to better academic performance. Traditional classrooms also provide opportunities for group discussions, debates, and collaborative projects, promoting critical thinking, creativity, and problem-solving skills. Furthermore, face-to-face interactions with instructors allow for immediate feedback and guidance, helping students clarify doubts and misconceptions. Overall, traditional classrooms offer a well-rounded learning experience that online platforms often cannot replicate.

When it comes to dining out, I always prefer eating at restaurants over food stands. The main reason for this is the ambiance and comfort that restaurants provide. At a restaurant, I can sit down, relax, and enjoy my meal in a clean and comfortable environment. In contrast, food stands are often crowded and noisy, with limited seating options. Additionally, restaurants typically have a wider variety of menu options, which allows me to try new dishes and flavors. Furthermore, the service at restaurants is usually more attentive and personalized, making the overall dining experience more enjoyable. Overall, I believe that eating at restaurants offers a more satisfying and enjoyable experience than eating at food stands.

A true friend is someone who possesses three essential qualities: support, care, and trust. Firstly, a true friend offers support in times of need, providing a listening ear and a helping hand. They stand by your side through thick and thin, never leaving you to face challenges alone. Secondly, a true friend shows care and concern for your well-being, celebrating your successes and mourning your failures. They are genuinely invested in your happiness and growth. Lastly, a true friend is trustworthy, keeping confidences and being honest with you, even when it's difficult. With these qualities, a true friend becomes a lifelong companion, making life's journey more meaningful and enjoyable.

As a college student in Beijing, I was thrilled to experience the vibrant energy of this megacity. The bustling streets, towering skyscrapers, and rich cultural heritage captivated me. From trying delicious street food to exploring ancient temples, every day was a new adventure. I was amazed by the city's blend of tradition and modernity, where ancient hutongs coexisted with sleek shopping malls. Beijing's charm lies in its ability to balance chaos and tranquility, making it an ideal place for students like me to grow and thrive. My college experience in Beijing was a journey of self-discovery, and I left with unforgettable memories and a newfound appreciation for urban life.

Enrolling in engineering school was the turning point that transformed my life. Prior to this, I felt lost and uncertain about my future. However, the moment I stepped into the engineering classroom, I knew I had made the right decision. The rigorous coursework and projects challenged me to think critically and creatively, helping me discover my strengths and passions. As I progressed, I developed a sense of purpose and direction, which boosted my confidence and motivation. Engineering school became a new chapter in my life, opening doors to opportunities and experiences that I never thought possible. It was a turning point that empowered me to shape my own destiny.

Daily homework is a crucial aspect of a child's academic journey, playing a significant role in their academic success and fostering family bonding. Homework helps children reinforce learning concepts, develop study habits, and improve time management skills, ultimately leading to better academic performance. Moreover, daily homework encourages children to take ownership of their learning, promoting independence and self-motivation. Additionally, homework provides an opportunity for parents to engage with their children, offering guidance and support, and strengthening family bonds. This collaborative effort helps parents stay informed about their child's academic progress, enabling them to identify areas that require extra attention. By making daily homework a priority, parents can contribute to their child's academic success and nurture a deeper connection with them.

As a child, I was fascinated by the way things worked. I would spend hours disassembling and reassembling toys, appliances, and even my siblings' gadgets. This curiosity sparked a dream in me to become an engineer. Now, as I stand at the threshold of my professional journey, I am more determined than ever to turn that dream into a reality. I am pursuing a career in engineering because it allows me to combine my passion for problem-solving, creativity, and innovation to make a tangible impact on people's lives. I am excited to contribute to the development of cutting-edge technologies that can improve the world and leave a lasting legacy.

My ideal of a perfect man is embodied in the inspiring character of Alan Shore, a fictional lawyer from the TV series Boston Legal. What makes him perfect is his unwavering commitment to justice, compassion, and humanity. He is a champion of the underdog, fighting for the rights of the marginalized and oppressed. His unorthodox approach to law and life is refreshing, and his willingness to challenge the status quo is admirable. Alan's character inspires me to stand up for what I believe in, even in the face of adversity, and to always strive to make a positive difference in the world.

I have always been fascinated by the endless possibilities that computer science offers. Among various reasons, two compelling reasons why I prefer computer science are its versatility and constant evolution. Firstly, computer science is an incredibly versatile field that allows me to explore various areas of interest, from artificial intelligence to cybersecurity. This flexibility enables me to develop a broad range of skills, making me a more competitive candidate in the job market. Secondly, the field of computer science is constantly evolving, with new technologies and innovations emerging every day. This rapid pace of change excites me, as it provides endless opportunities for growth and learning. By pursuing computer science, I am confident that I will stay at the forefront of technological advancements and make a meaningful impact in the world.

Maintaining physical and mental health is crucial for overall well-being. As a busy individual, I have developed strategies to ensure I prioritize my health. Physically, I engage in regular exercise such as jogging and yoga to keep my body active and flexible. I also follow a balanced diet, rich in fruits and vegetables, to provide my body with essential nutrients. Mentally, I practice mindfulness and meditation to reduce stress and anxiety. I also set aside time for self-reflection and journaling to process my emotions and thoughts. Additionally, I make sure to get adequate sleep and take breaks throughout the day to recharge. By incorporating these strategies into my daily routine, I am able to maintain a healthy balance between my physical and mental health.

Leonardo DaVinci's Mona Lisa is one of the most iconic paintings in the world, and her enigmatic smile is a major reason for its allure. The subtle, knowing curve of her lips seems to convey a thousand different emotions, inviting the viewer to ponder her secrets. With his characteristic sfumato technique, DaVinci created a soft, hazy effect that adds to the mystery of the smile. The Mona Lisa's smile is both captivating and elusive, making her an eternal source of fascination for art lovers. It is a testament to DaVinci's genius that his masterpiece continues to inspire and intrigue us to this day.

Despite its reputation, mini-golf is a deceptively challenging game. The unforgiving neon green turf and jagged rock formations always seem to send my ball careening in the wrong direction, ultimately ending up in the roaring waterfall. My younger sister, on the other hand, effortlessly navigates the obstacles and sinks her ball into the hole with ease, followed by an embarrassing victory dance that leaves me dismayed. 

However, my lack of mini-golf skills belies my passion for the game of golf itself. As the sole girl on my high school's golf team, I've earned the nickname "golf girl" from my peers. Growing up, I was inspired by my father's coaching and watching the LPGA with my grandfather, which instilled in me a love for the game. I looked up to talented women like Annika Sörenstam, who played with grace and power, and I was determined to make them proud. 

When I was cut from the middle school golf team, I was devastated, but I didn't give up. I practiced tirelessly, taking over 100 swings every night and spending hours on the putting green, dreaming of that match-winning putt. The sense of accomplishment I felt when I made the team the following season was incredible. 

Over the past six years, I've grown accustomed to the quirks and humor of my male teammates. At our first match, I was intimidated by the four teams of tall, strong boys, but my teammate James broke the ice with a bizarre joke that put me at ease. As we played together, our team dynamic evolved into a tight-knit group of friends who supported each other on and off the course. 

As the daughter of two teachers, I didn't have access to country club simulators or elite courses. So, two summers ago, I took matters into my own hands and got a job at the local country club, cleaning carts and taking out the trash. It wasn't glamorous, but it allowed me to play for free, and by the end of the summer, I realized that my hard work had leveled the playing field with my more affluent opponents. 

Golf has become an integral part of my life, bringing me joy and gratitude with every sunk putt and well-driven ball. Even though my sister still celebrates her mini-golf victories with a dance in the parking lot, I'll join her, knowing that I'll continue to play and learn from the game for the rest of my life.

As I trudged up the endless stone steps, my bruised shins and dirt-filled fingernails a testament to my journey, I found myself wondering: "How many times did I wake up at 4:15 a.m. this summer?" The answer, I knew, was twenty-two. I was determined to conquer the 48th peak before school started, fulfilling a goal I had set in fifth grade after meeting a group of inspiring Appalachian Trail through-hikers. Climbing all 48 four-thousand-foot peaks in New Hampshire was a daunting task that took some people a lifetime to complete. Now, at 6:15 a.m., I was gasping for air and questioning who was responsible for my pain. Perhaps it was my parents, who had instilled in me a love for the wilderness from a young age.

Growing up, my family had taken a different path. Instead of luxury resorts, we opted for camping trips and exploring the great outdoors. I had been fortunate enough to experience the world in a unique way, from running from wild cattle in the Italian Alps to pedaling through Oregon's hilly streets on a three-person bike. These experiences had given me a sense of adventure and a passion for hiking and backpacking.

The 48 climbs had been grueling, but they had also rewarded me with breathtaking vistas. On lucky days, we would end our journey at a mountain hut, sipping hot chocolate and devouring books on rare lichen. It was at one of these huts that I met a female naturalist, who introduced me to the endangered alpine flora and sparked my desire to become a hands-on environmentalist.

Now, as I stood at the base of Mount Isolation, my final peak, I felt a mix of emotions. The 13.6-mile hike was my last push, and I was ready. The initial struggle gave way to a stunning view of the Atlantic Ocean, with Mt. Washington glowing like amber in the distance. I was overcome with emotion, tears of joy and sadness streaming down my face. I had done it. I had achieved my goal.

As I began my descent, I realized that I had no one to blame for the early mornings and blisters. Instead, I wanted to thank my fifth-grade self for setting this goal. The struggles had been worth it, and I felt a sense of pride and accomplishment.

On the car ride home, music blasting and my feet wiggling in the wind, I felt like I was graduating from my childhood. Hiking with my family over the past seventeen years had created countless memories, but it was time for me to start a new chapter. I would continue to explore the wilderness, searching for rare specimens and marveling at the ordinary. The possibilities were endless, and I was excited to see what the future held.

As I stood on the ground, it began to shake beneath my feet. Suddenly, an oil truck erupted into flames before my eyes. A massive fireball illuminated the sky, leaving me awestruck. But just as quickly, hundreds of gallons of water poured down, extinguishing the blaze. "CUT!" a director yelled, and I cheered, thrilled by the scene I had just witnessed.

This childhood experience sparked my love for Hollywood. Disney's Hollywood Studios, with attractions like The Great Movie Ride and The Studio Backlot Tour, introduced me to the magic of special effects, illusions, and stunts. These early encounters hinted at my future passion for filmmaking, though I didn't realize it at the time.

Years later, my fascination with cinema remains unwavering. Whether it's a blockbuster, an Oscar contender, or a cult classic, I seize every opportunity to experience original films. For a few hours, I can escape into the on-screen universe, where characters come alive and their stories intertwine with my own experiences. As a self-proclaimed "tomboy" who loves football and dislikes dresses, I've drawn inspiration from strong female characters like Hermione Granger and Princess Leia. Seeing them stand up for themselves has boosted my confidence and encouraged me to stay true to myself.

My passion for film extends beyond characterization to the technical aspects of cinema. Cinematographers and lighting designers work magic, evoking emotions and awe in audiences. I'm eager to learn more about the craft and tackle the challenges of producing a film. When I do, I'll pour my heart into it, perhaps creating a protagonist who defies stereotypes and embodies my own quirks and passions.

What I love most about movies is their uniqueness to the individual creator. No two people can make the same film, as each director weaves their soul into their work. Whether I pursue filmmaking as a career or hobby, I hope to spread a message of hope, perseverance, and strength. If I can inspire just one person through my characters, I'll consider myself successful. Even if I don't break box office records, I'll have achieved my goal if I can make a positive impact on someone's life through my work.

In modern times, birds have lost their status as favored domestic animals to dogs and cats. At best, they are a fleeting presence in the sky, and at worst, they are seen as pests associated with filth and disease. However, for many centuries, birds held a revered place in folklore and tales from cultures around the world. 

We are all familiar with stories featuring birds as central characters: the wise owl, the mischievous raven, the vain peacock, and the motherly hen. I was introduced to these stories at a young age, captivated by the avian parables on CDs, which became an integral part of my childhood. I still remember proudly reciting "The Ant and the Magpie" to my parents, a tale that taught the importance of saving resources for times of need. As I grew older, my love for birds persisted, but the influence of those stories waned. After all, none of my classmates attributed their love of dogs to a Danish fairytale or Chinese folklore. I assumed my love for birds was superficial, stemming from their colorful plumage and joyful calls. Birds were no longer a central part of my identity; instead, they became a casual answer to the question of my favorite animal.

It wasn't until I stumbled upon one of my favorite childhood books, "Why Snails Have Shells," in my closet during high school that I rediscovered the significance of the lessons I learned from those cherished bird characters. Rereading the familiar stories, I realized that the straightforward teachings of the birds were more relevant to my life than they ever were in my childhood. Birds once again became more than just my favorite animal; they guided my reactions to challenging situations, which came in abundance as I grew older.

One lesson that has permeated my life is an old Chinese proverb, famously summed up by poet Maya Angelou: "A bird doesn't sing because it has an answer, it sings because it has a song." In today's high school environment, where social media dominates and approval from others is paramount, it's easy to get caught up in seeking validation. However, the bird's song reminds me of the importance of doing things for my own happiness, not others. I've adopted this mantra as a guiding principle, focusing on building genuine relationships, investing in activities I love, and expressing myself in ways that bring me joy. Although the stories and proverbs I learned as a child originated from distant times and places, they have woven themselves into my values and shaped me into the person I am today.

YouTube has been my mentor, teaching me everything from the simplest tasks, like toasting bread, to my current passion, dance. I vividly remember one night, sitting on the guest room rug, phone in hand, determined to learn a breakdancing move called the coffee grinder. I spent an hour practicing, and when I finally mastered it, I felt an overwhelming sense of joy and accomplishment. However, my excitement got the better of me, and I ended up breaking the table leg. My mom rushed in, and I was met with a look of disappointment. It was a setback, but it didn't deter me from pursuing my passion.

Growing up, I didn't have much to be proud of. I was a dreamer, imagining myself as an incredible dancer, drummer, or computer scientist. But I didn't have the opportunities to pursue these dreams. So, I started teaching myself dance at the age of 12, relying solely on YouTube tutorials and practice. It wasn't easy, but it's the foundation of my art.

Now, I face the challenge of competing with people who have had access to tutors, classes, and workshops. They have had the opportunity to travel and learn from the best, while I've had to work twice as hard to achieve half of what they have. But I'm driven by my passion to prove that anyone can create something from nothing.

When I started at King's as a freshman, I had the opportunity to work with my first dance teacher, Mr. Ryuji Yamaguchi. He introduced me to styles of dance that were considered taboo in Arab culture, and encouraged me to experiment and push boundaries. As the annual dance concert approached, I practiced tirelessly, determined to show the world what I was capable of. The night of the concert arrived, and I danced my heart out, performing in contemporary duets, group pieces, hip-hop solos, and Bollywood. The final bow was a moment of pure triumph, and I caught a glimpse of my mother's tearful eyes and proud smile. In that moment, I knew that I had finally broken free from the shackles that had held me back.

For me, art is utopia. It's the most rewarding work anyone can do, pouring hours of effort into creating something beautiful and unique. When you've invested all your energy into expressing your thoughts and ideas, you get to step back, admire your work, and say with pride, "I created this."

As a teenager, I'm expected to do my fair share of household chores, but growing up in a 234-year-old tavern has given me a unique set of responsibilities. Beyond feeding the dogs and mowing the lawn, I've had to deal with unexpected challenges like rescuing chimney swifts from my room and shoveling snow off my bedroom floor during a Nor'Easter. While I sometimes envy my friends' newer, more weather-tight homes, I know I wouldn't trade my quirky, old Harvard, Massachusetts home for anything.

Since my parents bought the tavern as a fixer-upper, I've been recruited to help with various projects, from glazing windows to painting rooms. This past summer, I reluctantly agreed to help repair the mortar joints in our basement's fieldstone foundation. The task required hauling 80-pound bags of cement, mixing it with water, and stuffing it into the deep crevices between the stones. As I worked, often on my hands and knees, I had plenty of time for self-reflection. Uninterrupted by technology, I let my mind wander, pondering conversations with friends, political issues, and essay topics.

As I worked with my hands, I realized that forming and sculpting the cement was a creative process, much like writing and editing. It was an iterative and exhausting process, but the sense of accomplishment was worth it. I was reminded of my experience rowing in the Head of the Fish Regatta, where I had to push through physical exhaustion to finish.

Good mortaring, like eventing, requires technical precision, speed, and strength. It demands perseverance, attention to detail, and the ability to work through discomfort. As I worked on the wall, I recognized that these same qualities are essential for achieving any mental or physical goal, whether it's winning a competition, writing an essay, or rebuilding a wall. Standing back from the finished wall, I felt a sense of pride and accomplishment, not just in completing the task, but in discovering the zen in the art of mortar maintenance.

As I descended into the basement of Washington Studio School for my first sculpting class, the air was thick with red dust. I had come seeking a creative outlet after a stressful day. Behind the thick curtain, I found a room covered in a fine layer of that same dust, with bookshelves sporting a small collection of sculptures. Our task was to transform a 4' by 6' block of clay into a seated woman, modeled after the one sitting before us.

I stared at the block, unsure where to begin. The woman beside me, however, was already shaping her rust-colored slab with ease. She added clumps to the top, subtracted pieces to form shoulders and arms, and I found myself mesmerized by her process. I was in awe of her ability to see the woman hidden within the clay.

Eventually, I turned back to my own sculpture and tentatively shaved off a small piece from the top corner. I continued to work on that corner, afraid to make any drastic changes. When my instructor visited my table, he offered suggestions, shaving away clay and encouraging me to remove even more. But I was hesitant, fearful of making mistakes that would be permanent.

This fear of impermanence held me back throughout the three-hour lesson. By the end, my piece resembled Mario from Super Mario Bros. rather than the model before me. As I left the class, I wondered when I had started letting fear dictate my actions.

I recalled a time when I would boldly leap into new situations. Like the time I jumped off a chair lift 8 feet too soon, and my dad caught me. I had lost that fearlessness, and I was determined to reclaim it.

The following week, I approached my sculpture with a newfound sense of courage. I took out clumps of clay, rather than slivers. When my instructor visited, he pointed out numerous flaws: the arm was too high, the legs resembled a yeti's, and the head was balloon-shaped. But I was proud to be taking risks and enjoying the process.

My final piece was far from perfect, riddled with errors. Yet, I had come to appreciate those mistakes, and the journey they represented. Every crack, air bubble, and slip was a testament to my growth. I realized that, like my sculpture, I had been shaped by my mistakes, and that as long as I wanted to continue becoming myself, I would need to keep making them.

Three years ago, I would have written this essay with unbridled passion, declaring my desire to become a cardiologist. I would have shared how cardiology had revealed my true purpose: saving lives. I would have highlighted how it leveraged my strengths, attention to detail and empathy, and how it allowed me to repay the debt of gratitude I owed to my mother's cardiologist, who had given her a second chance at life. But that was then. Today, I no longer harbor that dream. The truth is, my passion for cardiology was a fabrication, a misguided notion of what I thought was just.

In reality, I have a way with words, a lyrical quality that is the essence of my being. I am a writer, and with every word I craft, a part of my soul takes flight, transcending time and space. For years, I had been writing about cardiology and science, deceiving myself into believing that my passion for writing was a passion for the medical field. I would write novels about my experiences as a cardiologist, but it was all a ruse. My love for writing had become so pronounced that I mistook it for a passion for cardiology.

As a child, I never recognized writing as more than a hobby. But the truth is, it is who I am. Despite my undying love for this art form, I would tell myself that cardiology was my true calling, even though I felt disconnected from it. It wasn't until I heard a simple yet profound sentence - "If you do something you love, you never have to work a day in your life" - that I realized my mistake. This sentence unlocked a new chapter in my life's story, redirecting my thoughts from who I was to who I wanted to be. And in that moment, my heart belonged to writing.

I had always feared that others wouldn't understand my love for writing, that they wouldn't grasp the depth of my connection to it. But writing is not just descriptive language; it is the core of my being, engraved in my soul. Without it, I would cease to exist. Writing liberates me, allowing me to think and be whoever I want to be. I had begun a story I thought I knew by heart, but the words had drifted, and my true love and destiny had become clear: becoming a writer.

As I reflect on my life, I've grown accustomed to the amused glances I receive when I confess my passion for Legos to my friends. Growing up in a chaotic household with four siblings, I desperately needed an escape from the mayhem. Building Lego sets became my sanctuary, a way to calm my mind and focus on a single task. My first Lego set was a gift on my seventh birthday, and although I was excited, I was also perplexed by the challenge it presented. With persistence and help from others, I eventually mastered the art of building.

As I grew older, I continued to request Legos as gifts, determined to hone my skills. The breakthrough came when I completed my first kit, a miniature Seattle Space Needle, entirely on my own. This accomplishment sparked a sense of pride and creativity, transforming my bedroom floor into a studio where I could let my imagination run wild. I discovered that I was capable of creating unique sculptures and designs that I never would have conceived without my obsession with those tiny plastic blocks.

As I entered my teenage years, my Lego creations became more sophisticated, and I began to envision designing and constructing real-world buildings and entities. My bedroom floor evolved into a sprawling metropolis, reminiscent of New York City's iconic skyline. Returning home from school or a grueling practice, I found solace in my personalized city, a testament to my imagination and creativity.

Although I no longer build Lego structures regularly, my passion for those tiny bricks instilled in me a sense of curiosity and creativity that will forever be a part of me. When I arrived at boarding school as a first-year student, I was anxious and hesitant. Seeking an escape from my anxiety, I enrolled in a ceramics and sculpting class. This new medium allowed me to express myself in a different way, and I soon found myself constructing complex designs and transferring them to my personal studio, my bedroom, where they joined my Lego creations.

Legos have left an indelible mark on my life, fostering my capacity to experiment with new endeavors and cultivating my imagination, creativity, and optimism. As I continue to design my sculptures, write my essays, and shape my future, I am guided by the lessons I learned from those humble plastic blocks.

Here is a rewritten version of the passage:

Hurricane Maria's devastating impact on Puerto Rico hit close to home, as my Massachusetts city became a refuge for those fleeing the island. But in a community where nearly half the population is Puerto Rican, I was shocked to hear my French and Irish uncle question why they were coming to our city, citing concerns about overcrowded schools and resources. His words were all the more hurtful because they implied that the struggles of Puerto Rican refugees were less important than those of his own son, who lacked an AP English book. It was a painful reminder of the ignorance that can surround our identities.

As I grew older, I began to notice the subtle yet insidious ways that racism and intolerance can manifest in those closest to us. I've heard loved ones make thoughtless jokes, only to follow up with a condescending "not you, you're not really Puerto Rican." These comments left me feeling like I didn't belong, like I needed to assimilate into the dominant culture to be accepted. Even family gatherings, like Thanksgiving with my white cousins, could be alienating experiences. It was only when I was surrounded by my Puerto Rican cousins at my Abuela's house that I felt a sense of community and connection to my heritage.

But even then, I couldn't escape the feeling of being an outsider. People would ask if I was Muslim or Italian, as if my ethnicity was a puzzle to be solved. They would compliment my "exotic" name, only to reveal their own biases when they learned about my mixed heritage. It was as if my identity was a constant source of fascination and curiosity, rather than a fundamental aspect of who I am.

Working at a grocery store in a neighboring town, I saw firsthand how Hurricane Harvey victims received an outpouring of support, while Puerto Rico's struggles were largely ignored. It was a stark reminder that not all adversities are created equal in the eyes of society.

But I've come to realize that my identity is not defined by the glances or comments of others. I am more than my heritage, more than my skin color or accent. I am a daughter, a student, a friend, a sister. I am the sum of my passions, experiences, and relationships. I am a complex, multifaceted individual, and my identity cannot be reduced to a single characteristic or stereotype.

Growing up at the intersection of different cultures and identities has taught me the importance of empathy and understanding. It's only when we put ourselves in others' shoes, when we strive to see the world from their perspective, that we can begin to overcome our own biases and prejudices. My white uncle may never fully understand what it's like to be a minority, but that doesn't mean he can't try. By acknowledging and confronting our own ignorance, we can work towards a more inclusive and compassionate society.

At the age of 6, I began to measure my life in terms of flipped pages, packed boxes, and school maps. As my family and I moved from state to state, coast to coast, for my father's job over the past decade, I found solace in fantasy novels. With my head propped against the baseboard near my nightlight, I would escape into whimsical forests, fight daring battles, and rule over treacherous courts long after dark. In these fantastical worlds, I could be anyone: the queen, the knight, the hero, or even the villain. These books allowed me to express emotions I couldn't have imagined on my own - happiness, anger, sadness, and queerness.

The characters I discovered in novels during my library and bookstore tours across the country taught me resilience and empowered me to nurture my strengths. Mare Barrow inspired me to strive for academic excellence, earning a 4.4 GPA. Tane from The Priory of the Orange Tree motivated me to push my physical limits, leading me to traverse over 1,544 miles in cross-country races and practices. Evelyn Hugo's unapologetic character emboldened me to embrace my queerness rather than hide it. This year, I'm taking my love of fantasy to the next level by playing Mrs. White in my school's production of Shuddersome and The Monkey's Paw, drawing inspiration from Anne of Green Gables, my first fictional idol, who shaped my personality and flair for drama.

Above all, my favorite author, Leigh Bardugo, gave me the courage to write and dream big. What started as a safety net in my adolescence has grown into a true passion for English and its limitless expressive power. Language is power, and I want to wield it like a mighty sword. I aspire to be a New York Times bestseller, to know that my work makes a difference, no matter how small. I want to see my book in the hands of strangers, refusing to put it down, just as I did in the hallways of my middle school.

I want to be a writer, a college professor, a publishing lawyer - I want it all, the triumphs and the setbacks. Without literature, I wouldn't be the person I am today. Without the constant moves and library hauls, I wouldn't have discovered my love for English, nor would I be as resilient, adaptable, and adventurous. With every move, I burrowed into books, and with every book, I became more myself. Literature has shaped me in every way, and the only way I can repay it is to become the writer I've always dreamed of being.

I dreaded the arrival of the cicadas. In 1987, 2004, and again in 2021, these tyrannical insects swarmed DC and neighboring areas, and I was particularly anxious about Brood X, the most notorious of them all. Brood X is a cluster of cicadas that descends upon Washington, D.C. every 17 years, and I have the misfortune of living in the epicenter of their swarm. To me, cicadas were right up there with mosquitoes in the top tier of human annoyances. I loathed these off-brand cockroaches.

But as I reflected on their life cycle, I began to see some unexpected parallels with my own life. For 17 years, cicadas live underground, feeding on sap and avoiding danger. Then, they emerge into the real world, much like I've been sheltered by my parents for 17 years, living in the same house and town, with them providing for me and keeping me safe. Is it possible that I have more in common with cicadas than I initially thought?

Like cicadas, I've been feeling a bit disoriented and blurry-eyed after a year of Zoom classes, tele-health appointments, and excessive social media and video game use. And, I have to admit, I do make a racket with my noisy blender and loud music, and I can be a bit of a mess-maker. But at least I don't leave behind damaged wings, shed skin, or rotting carcasses everywhere.

As I thought more about it, I realized that cicadas and I are more alike than I initially thought. After 17 years of being cooped up, we're both eager to spread our wings and face new experiences. Cicadas want to explore the world, even if it means colliding into obstacles, and I want to escape to college, even if it means getting lost or making mistakes.

Just as the hardiest cicadas survive their emergence and go on to thrive, I want to be a resilient Brood X cicada, willing to learn from my mistakes and keep moving forward. I'll need time to figure things out, but I'm ready to take on the challenges of college and emerge stronger on the other side. When I look beyond our differences, I see that there's room for all creatures to grow and thrive, whether they're cicadas or humans.

I was born to two moms, Meredith, my biological mother, and Mary, my adoptive mother. Because they were a same-sex couple, Mary had to adopt me to become my legal parent. They used a sperm donor, known only as Sperm Donor 3311, and I've never known my biological father. All I know about him is that he has no history of cancer, a twin brother who's 6'4", and studied math in school. He's a stranger to me, and I'm just a secret to him.

People often ask about my father, and I'm forced to correct them, saying, "I actually have two moms." This usually sparks reactions like my driving instructor's awkward comment, "Oh, well that must be different." Even at 17, I'm still unsure how to respond to these kinds of comments.

When I was just 5, Mary passed away after a long battle with leukemia. My world was turned upside down, and I was old enough to understand the grief that followed. I still wonder what I missed out on and feel guilty for not remembering much about Mary, since we didn't have enough time together. Many people say that grief gets easier with time, but I think it just changes shape.

After Mary's passing, my biological mom, Meredith, met another woman, Kerry, who became my stepmom. To me, Kerry is also my mom. Now, instead of getting reactions to having two moms, I get reactions to having three. But not knowing my father doesn't leave a void in my life. My moms are the ones who sang silly songs, took me on adventures, and taught me about love and acceptance.

I've never known a father figure, so I don't feel like I'm missing out on anything. My moms have shown me that family is about love, not biology. I've learned to embrace differences and accept everyone around me. I'm excited to build relationships in the future, knowing that there's no one "normal" way to be a family.

My upbringing has taught me that I can accomplish anything, but it's also shown me that there are limits. We have to research destinations to ensure they're gay-friendly, and we avoid places like Jamaica, where we wouldn't be accepted. I may not know about my dad's side of the family, but I can talk about the people who raised me with love and pride.

The world is changing, and "normal" is becoming a thing of the past. For me, it's already a distant memory. I wouldn't trade my family for anything, and I own that every day.

As I walk through the Chechen mountains with a boy even younger than my 14 years, he explains the difference between anti-personnel and anti-tank mines in halting Russian. I'm struck by the harsh realities that kids half my age have already learned the hard way. My guide points out the overgrown grass and abundant fruit trees, areas that people and animals avoid due to the presence of landmines. It's a jarring contrast to my life in London, and it's hard to reconcile with my father's rosy stories about his childhood in Katyr-Yurt.

As I experience the beauty of the place, I'm also confronted with the less romanticized parts of my family's past. I grew up speaking Russian with my Muscovite, Jewish mother, but the Chechen children speak in broken Russian, and the adults are hesitant to communicate in the language of their enemy. Seeing the physical and psychological scars of war, I feel like an intruder, ashamed of my Russianness and my city-boy naivete.

Despite this shame, I yearn to understand what it means to be Chechen, to see their home through their eyes. This desire sparks a deep connection to the land, and I begin to explore the conflicting layers of my familial identity. In Moscow, my awareness of these conflicting identities intensifies, particularly on the maternal side of my heritage. Relatives view Chechens as terrorists, and I'm met with distrust and fear when I share my experiences.

When I return to London, I'm unable to slip back into my old life. I find myself pondering the question of identity and how people interpret their own past, influenced by collective emotion and memory as much as fact. The cosmopolitanism of London takes on a new light, and I'm drawn to conversations about personal histories and complicated identities. I want to learn about my friends' experiences, many of whom are also children of immigrants to the UK. When did they explore their own identities? How did these discoveries make them feel? What does it mean to carry the stories, poetry, and pain of multiple places within them?

These questions, which were crucial for me to answer about myself, become a powerful way to understand the people around me and the complex world we share.

Here is a rewritten version of the passage:

As I stood poised to perform, I felt a surge of confidence. Two months of intense preparation had readied my fingers for this momentous concert. I had carefully selected three pieces for my repertoire: Erik Satie's soothing Gymnopedie No. 1, Beethoven's haunting First Movement of the Moonlight Sonata, and Bach's airy Prelude in C Major. As I walked onto the stage, I felt a sense of respect and prestige emanating from the audience.

I took my seat, and the chair creaked in sympathy with the audience's anticipation. I arranged my sheet music and began to play. The performance was exhilarating, with every technique and trick I had practiced executed flawlessly. I brought Satie's phonological experiment to life with varying pressure on each chord, and Beethoven's cascading arpeggios resonated with unity and precision. The room was filled with bliss as I concluded with Bach's Well-Tempered Clavier.

As I took my final bow, the audience erupted into applause, and I beamed with pride. But then, a faint question pierced the din: "Could you play something more lively, darling, like a Neil Diamond song?" I was taken aback by Mrs. Hersch's request, feeling my feathers ruffled by her disregard for the masterpieces I had just performed.

As I reflected on the event, I realized that my visceral reaction was unwarranted. Why had I been so hesitant to accommodate a simple request made in earnestness? It would have been easier to practice "Sweet Caroline" than to struggle with Beethoven's work. I came to understand that my choice of musical pieces mattered little as long as my audience enjoyed them. Whether it was a tortured pop song or a masterfully crafted concerto, I vowed to play them all.

Working with the elderly at the long-term-care facility had taught me a valuable lesson. Despite my mentors' platitudes, I had learned that the world didn't revolve around my tastes and interests. And so, I began to practice "Sweet Caroline" in earnest, preparing for my next recital with a newfound appreciation for the diverse preferences of my audience.

As I hiked through the charred remains of the forest fire in Philmont, New Mexico, I felt an overwhelming sense of grief and emotion emanating from the space. The once-thriving Ponderosa Pines, now blackened and brittle, seemed to whisper their laments through the wind. The landscape was a haunting reminder of loss, with every pile of scorched timber and wavering shadow cast by the hollow towers of ash telling a story of devastation.

I thought I was prepared when I joined the Scouts BSA program, drawn by my love of nature, camping, and the sense of community it provided. But nothing could have prepared me for the challenges I would face as the first female "boy scout" in my town. It was both an honor and a constant reminder of the isolation and insecurity that comes with being a trailblazer. I felt like an imposter, lacking the strong will and leadership skills that seemed to come naturally to others who had paved the way.

As I navigated the challenges of being a "first," my doubts and insecurities echoed through the forest, much like the burnt trees that seemed to whisper their laments. But it was during a backpacking trip in Philmont Scout Ranch that I began to find my footing. The rugged terrain, steep cliffs, and vibrant meadows pushed me to my limits, but it was the forest that had burned decades ago that left a lasting impression. The fire had cleared the land, leaving behind a signature of charred trees, but also a blanket of wild grasses and flowers that seemed to stretch on forever.

In the end, it was this experience that helped me earn my Eagle Rank, the culmination of my time as a scout. I realized that being a "first" isn't about being a fierce leader, but about putting in the extra hours, listening to criticism, and using your own feelings of isolation to connect with others. It's about going through the fire and emerging stronger on the other side. As I look back on my experience in Philmont, it's not the blackened graveyard of trees that I remember most vividly, but the soft purple wildflowers that managed to thrive in the desert soil, a testament to the power of resilience and growth.

Here is a rewritten version of the passage:

At six years old, I'm swept up in the lively sounds of hornpipes and laughter that fill the makeshift auditorium. My mom catches me dancing to her old Irish tapes - the Chieftains, Sinead O'Connor - and asks if I want to learn for real. I nod eagerly, and she hands me a pair of worn, dusty black shoes that are too big for my feet. A freckled woman reassures me, "Don't worry, you'll learn eventually." As I approach the stage, twenty-five pairs of eyes lock onto me, and for a moment, everything stands still. It doesn't matter that I feel like a clown in oversized shoes; all that matters is the dancing.

At nine years old, I sit in the hallway of the Times Square Marriott, watching girls in big wigs and sparkly dresses flutter around like glamorous, unhinged chickens. In my simple tartan skirt and bun, I feel like an ugly duckling. The bobby pins digging into my scalp make me ache, and my hands slide to my shoes, which are too tight after Mom tried to stretch them out. As I take the stage, a hundred pairs of eyes fix on me, and in the bustling hotel, everything stands still. It doesn't matter that I'm out of place; all that matters is the dancing.

At twelve years old, my mind is a jumble of worst-case scenarios as I stand with my teammates in a hotel in Orlando, Florida. We've sacrificed everything for this moment, and I try to focus on happy thoughts: Dad's proud face, the freedom of flying across the stage. We recite our steps like a poem, the sequences like a song that carries us through the ocean of fiddles, pipes, and drums. My parents have sacrificed so much for me to be here; I want to make them proud, make myself proud. As we approach the national stage, a thousand pairs of eyes fix on me, and in the world bustling with motion, everything stands still. It doesn't matter that I feel like a fraud; all that matters is the dancing.

At fifteen years old, an Irish accent lilts through the ballroom of the World Championships, evoking mashed potatoes, Sunday bests, and the green hills of home. We mutter a prayer, though I'm not sure I believe in God. I glance at my partner, wishing we were more than friends, and she smiles. I'm not sure God believes in me either. As we ascend the stage, a million pairs of eyes fix on me, and in the universe bustling with motion, everything stands still. It doesn't matter that I'll never be enough; all that matters is the dancing.

In the future, when I'm eighteen, murmuring voices will hover in the air of the gymnasium-turned-cafeteria-turned-auditorium. A little girl will approach me timidly, wearing a very old tartan skirt. I'll adjust her bun to soothe her aching scalp, then slide my hands toward her feet, toward a pair of small, dusty shoes. "You'll learn," I'll reassure her. "Don't worry, you'll grow into them." Then, we'll look at my own beloved shoes, worn but full of stories. I'll tell her the creases are like a map, evidence of the places I've been, the heartbreaks I've suffered, the joy I've danced. My life is in these shoes. As the music begins to play, the tide of fiddles, pipes, and drums, I'll take her hand, and with a deep breath, we'll climb the stage. "Ahd mor." It won't matter that this is the end; all that has ever mattered is the dancing.

Here is a rewritten version of the passage:

As I paint, a dark void begins to descend upon the young girl standing in the idyllic meadow. It creeps up on her, reaching for her pristine white dress. But just as it's about to engulf her, I swipe my brush across the canvas, wiping away the paint in a panic. Before I can think, the dark shape morphs into an ugly smear of black paint. The peaceful scene I had created is gone, replaced by a mess.

All I can focus on is the offending smudge, and I'm filled with frustration. But then I hear Bob Ross's cheerful voice in my head, reminding me that "there are no mistakes, only happy accidents." I disagree - there's nothing happy about this mistake. But as I stare at the smudge, I feel a thrill of excitement. It's a challenge, a taunt to fix the painting that took me hours to create.

I refuse to let the mistake defeat me. I grab my painting and set it against the living room window, where the TV news anchor is droning on about the California wildfires. As I gaze out at the blood-orange sky, inspiration strikes. What if the black smudge isn't a void, but smoke creeping up on the girl as she watches the meadow burn?

I rush back to my room, fueled by a new vision. I grab my paints and create a palette of fiery hues - reds, oranges, and yellows that evoke the flames engulfing California. I add whites and blacks to create shades of gray, my ally and enemy. With bold strokes, I paint the flames around the girl, covering the serene landscape. Next, I attempt to create the hazy smoke, but it doesn't quite work. The gray paint looks like blobs, not clouds.

Frustrated, I crack my knuckles and a new idea strikes. I dip my fingers into the cold gray paint, warming it as I rub it between my fingers. As I apply it to the canvas, I feel the rough texture of the dried paint. With each stroke, the blobs transform into the hazy clouds I've been experiencing for weeks. The tension in my body releases as I work, and when I finally step back, I gaze upon a new creation. I've won.

As I make my way down a bustling street, I'm met with a flurry of curious glances and turned heads. The whispers and giggles swirl around me, punctuated by the occasional "Oh my God!" or "Damn!" It's a familiar sensation, one that I've learned to navigate with a mix of politeness and humor. When a stranger asks for a photo, I oblige, flashing a smile and laughing along with the strangers who surround me. It's a fleeting moment, one that ends with the click of the camera and the strangers disappearing into the crowd.

Sometimes, I wish I could blend in, to be just another face in the sea of people. But at 7 feet tall, that's a luxury I'll never know. Instead, I've learned to embrace the attention, even as it can be overwhelming at times. My friends remind me that my height is just one aspect of who I am, but as I reflect on my life, I realize that it has played a significant role in shaping my character.

For one, it's taught me to be comfortable in my own skin. If I had been introverted like my older brother, I might have been paralyzed by the constant attention. But instead, I've learned to own my uniqueness, to stand tall and proud. It's also taught me to be kind, to be gentle and welcoming to those around me. As a child, I was often mistaken for a bully simply because of my size, so I had to work extra hard to prove that I was a kind and gentle soul.

My height has also taught me humility. People expect a lot from someone who stands at 7 feet tall, and I've learned to temper those expectations with a healthy dose of humility. I've learned to work hard, to push myself to be better, and to laugh at myself when I fall short. And finally, it's taught me to be lighthearted, to laugh at the absurdity of it all. When people make fun of my height, I join in, because what's the point of taking yourself too seriously?

Through it all, I've developed a sense of confidence and articulateness that serves me well in all aspects of my life. I've learned to interact with people from all walks of life, to engage in conversations that are both meaningful and mundane. And in the end, I've come to realize that accepting who you are, quirks and all, is the first step to true happiness. Being a 7-footer is both a blessing and a curse, but it's a part of who I am, and I wouldn't change it for the world.

A debate teammate once suggested that I should exfoliate my skin every time I lost a round. I countered that it wasn't practical. He retorted that neither was my refusal to wear clothes in which I'd lost important debates, implying that my wardrobe choices were superstitious. While half of me agrees with him, the other half still clings to my rituals. For instance, I always bring three specific pencils to tests because I believe it improves my scores. I'm also convinced that using Calibri font in lab reports yields better grades. And, despite knowing it's irrational, I won't reuse clothes worn during lost debates. 

Although I value logic and strive for precision in my reasoning, I often make exceptions for my superstitions. Growing up in a multigenerational household, I was never short on advice, but I've developed a peculiar habit of rebelling against my Korean heritage by cooking Italian food during traditional holidays. My graph of physical activity versus time would resemble an irregular heartbeat, with peaks representing my surfing and debate team activities, and troughs symbolizing my research and piano practice. 

I find comfort in routine, like my midnight baking sessions with my brother, but I also cherish conversations with people from diverse backgrounds. Whether discussing research on female voting patterns in Kuwait or the nuances of college applications, I thrive on cultural exchanges with international debaters. My behavior may be unpredictable, but it's consistently so. While I may not conform to expectations, I'm always true to myself – even if that means cooking linguine whenever I catch a whiff of kimchi.

When my mother told me I listened to "white people music," I couldn't help but agree. Rock 'n' roll did originate in the basements of young, white men, after all. But I was quick to point out that its roots also lay in the jazz scene of the Harlem Renaissance, and that one of the greatest guitarists of all time, Jimi Hendrix, was black. My love affair with punk rock began in seventh grade, when Green Day's "Boulevard of Broken Dreams" randomly played on my iTunes. I delved deeper into their discography and soon found myself immersed in the world of punk. My mother, who grew up in a segregated New York, was more familiar with Stevie Wonder than Stevie Nicks, but she accepted my musical tastes.

As my friends listened to Taylor Swift and One Direction, I blasted Green Day, Ramones, and The Clash through my Hot Topic headphones. The raw energy and rebellious spirit of punk rock resonated deeply with me. It was as if I had found a community that understood me, a group of misfits who rejected the status quo and spoke out against injustice. I had always felt like an outsider in my prep school, where the goal was to be popular and conform to certain standards. But punk rock's anti-establishment ethos spoke to me, and I found solace in its message of nonconformity.

However, as I adopted the punk philosophy, I began to realize that I was more focused on being different than on being true to myself. I wasted energy on rejecting mainstream culture simply for the sake of it, rather than focusing on what genuinely made me happy. It wasn't until I transitioned to a new high school that I had the opportunity to reevaluate my approach. I started listening to a wider range of music, including genres that weren't strictly punk. I bought yoga pants and discovered they were comfortable. And I learned to appreciate the beauty of compromise.

My revised punk philosophy is simple: do what makes you happy, regardless of whether it fits into the "system" or not. As John Lennon so eloquently put it in "Revolution," "You tell me it's the institution / Well, you know / You'd better free your mind instead." Questioning authority doesn't have to mean opposing everything; sometimes, it's about finding what truly resonates with you. For me, that means striving to act on ideals like love and justice, rather than simply rebelling against the mainstream.

Perhaps I've failed the punk movement in some way, but I've come to realize that being true to oneself is the greatest form of rebellion. I'll wear my Doc Martens, drink my pumpkin spice latte, and blast my favorite guitar solo with pride. That's as punk as it gets.

Here is a rewritten version of the passage:

As I gazed at the cluttered desk in front of me, my eyes landed on a small kohl. With a shaky hand, I carefully applied the ebony powder to my waterline, wincing as the fine specks got into my eyes. The vibrant colors of my birthday makeup kit seemed to leap out at me, and I was determined to master the art of using them. At 12, I was still new to the world of makeup, but I was driven to unlock its secrets. After school, I would retreat to my bedroom, shutting myself in to practice and perfect my techniques. 

But my mom's unexpected visit one day brought me back down to earth. She chuckled at my smudged lipstick and uneven eyeliner, and I felt a flush of embarrassment. As she helped me clean up my mistakes, I realized that becoming a makeup expert would require some guidance. When I asked her about the ingredients in the bright powder she was using, she admitted she wasn't sure. Her suggestion that I find out for myself sparked a journey of discovery. Hours of research later, I learned that the powder was made from mica, a mineral commonly used in cosmetics - but one that was often sourced unethically and harmfully to the environment. 

Determined to reconcile my love of makeup with my values, I put my kit away, vowing to find more sustainable alternatives. Now, at 17, I approach makeup with a more nuanced understanding of its impact. As I glance at my old kit, I'm reminded of the journey it's taken me on. Without that reckoning, makeup would have remained just a tool for physical transformation, rather than a catalyst for personal growth. 

Today, each time I apply eyeliner or lipstick, I'm not just enhancing my appearance - I'm also writing a chapter in my children's book about conscious consumerism. I'm working on algorithms and models that promote supply chain transparency. Makeup has taught me to be fearless in my self-expression and my expectations for the future. I coat my lips with bold colors, preparing to speak out about urgent issues at conferences and in everyday conversations. I see my passion inspiring others to embark on their own journeys of self-discovery and activism. 

As I look in the mirror, I see a paradox - my skin is a canvas of creativity and activism, but it's also a reflection of my own identity. Perhaps that's why makeup fascinates me - it allows me to bring my imagination to life. Whether I'm channeling the Wicked Witch of the West or an Indian classical dancer, makeup gives me the freedom to explore different personas and express myself fully. And as I peel back the layers, I'm still the same curious, passionate person I've always been - driven to create positive change, one brushstroke at a time.

I was thrilled to land a volunteer opportunity at the Long Marine Lab, a renowned marine biology research facility at UC Santa Cruz. I had visions of swimming with dolphins or studying the behavior of decorator crabs. However, my excitement quickly turned to disappointment on my first day when I discovered that I would be sorting through albatross boluses, the indigestible materials they regurgitate before setting out to sea. After three hours of separating fishing line from brown muck, I began to dread the task ahead. At the time, I had no idea how fascinating this opportunity would turn out to be, and how it would remind me of my tendency to become engrossed in even the most unexpected topics.

Initially, I found the task of sorting through boluses tedious, but it didn't take long for my boredom to shift to curiosity. The project itself was fascinating, aiming to research the behavior and diet of albatrosses at sea. These incredible birds can fly for months without touching land, and when they have chicks, they regurgitate whatever they've eaten at sea to feed them. When the chicks become old enough to fly, they cough up the hard, indigestible materials left in their stomachs, which contain valuable information about their diet.

As I became more skilled at dissecting the boluses, I started to find remarkable things, and my colleagues and I would often discuss our significant discoveries. We would search for the largest squid beak, examine fish eyes, and occasionally stumble upon plastic artifacts like bottle caps, lighters, and even toothbrushes. The presence of these human-made objects was both shocking and fascinating, revealing the distant origins of the trash and the devastating impact of human activity on the oceans.

This experience taught me a valuable lesson: that even the most mundane tasks can be fascinating, and that there is beauty in the unexpected. As someone who plays piano and is passionate about various subjects, including albatrosses, particle physics, and history, I realized that I don't have to choose just one area to dedicate my life to. Instead, I can continue to explore and learn about different topics, always staying curious and engaged. With so many subjects to learn about, books to read, pieces to play, and albatrosses to save, I know that I will never be bored in life.

As I gaze up at the starry sky, I'm struck by the remnants of ancient cultures, constellations like Cygnus, Hercules, and Pisces. The sound of waves crashing on the beach reminds me of the powerful forces of nature at work. It's astonishing to think that stars are blazing spheres of fire and that electrical impulses are what make us sentient beings. The very existence of our world is a wonder, a delicate balance of components that work in harmony to support life. What are the odds that this particular planet developed all the necessary parts to make life possible? How do they interact, and how did they come to be?

I reflect on how my perspective has shifted over the past year. At Balboa, students are divided into small learning communities that are integrated into the curriculum. Initially, I had ranked the Law Academy as my top choice, but I was assigned to WALC, the Wilderness Arts and Literacy Collaborative, which I had ranked fourth. I was disappointed and felt bitter towards my classes. However, since students are required to wait at least a semester before switching pathways, I stayed in WALC. As it turned out, that semester marked a turning point in my thinking, shifting my focus from ambition to genuine interest.

WALC's integrated classes and trips to natural areas not only fostered a sense of community among students but also allowed us to explore complex natural processes and humanity's role in them. As I pieced together these lessons, I began to visualize the intricate workings of our universe. I could see the carving of glacial valleys, the creation and erosion of mountains, and the transportation of nutrients through ecosystems. I saw these forces at work on the surface of a tiny planet rotating on its axis and orbiting the sun, a precious gem in the vast universe.

Through WALC, I gained a deeper understanding of natural systems and developed an insatiable curiosity about the interconnectedness of our cosmos. Understanding the complex mechanics of a system not only satisfies my curiosity but also adds beauty to my world. My newfound appreciation for tectonic and gradational forces allows me to see mountains and coastlines in a new light, beyond their aesthetic appeal. By physically experiencing the natural wonders described in WALC's lessons, I've gained not only the tools to admire these systems but also a genuine appreciation for them.

This has created a thirst in me to discover more beauty in a world often marred by poverty and violence, and a hunger for knowledge to satisfy that thirst. With so many systems to examine and dissect – from universal to subatomic scales – I hope to explore my interests through a variety of college courses and contribute to humanity's understanding through research, ultimately inspiring a deeper appreciation for the complex systems that govern our universe.

James struggled to connect with the other campers. At lunch, he'd sit alone, engrossed in his own toys. During group activities, his peers would complain when paired with him. I, as the camp counselor, observed his behavior, but nothing seemed out of the ordinary. I couldn't understand why the other campers treated him like an outcast. After three days of exclusion, James broke down during a game of soccer, tears streaming down his face as he slumped off the field, head in his hands. I rushed towards him, concern etched on my forehead. Some campers snickered, "Why is that weirdo crying?" My heart swelled with indignation; they were the ones who had bullied him, calling him "James the Freak," and now they were mocking his tears. I firmly told them to keep their thoughts to themselves. I squatted beside James and asked what was wrong. Grunting, he turned his back to me. I needed to comfort him, so I spent the next hour chatting about topics a seven-year-old boy would love, from sports to Transformers. As James began to open up, I asked, "Why do the other campers exclude you?" Hesitantly, he removed his shoes and socks, revealing his left foot – he had four toes. It dawned on me that the other campers must have noticed during our swim two days prior. I recalled my own childhood, when even minor differences could lead to social exclusion. I finally understood. But how could I help? I racked my brain for the right words to soothe his pain. Nothing came to mind. On impulse, I hugged him – a gesture we camp leaders were discouraged from initiating, and an act I later discovered no friend had ever shown James before. Then, I placed my hand on his shoulder, looked him straight in the eye, and assured him that physical appearance didn't matter, and that as long as he was friendly, people would eventually come around. I listed successful individuals who had overcome their abnormalities. And finally, I told him he would always be my favorite camper, regardless of the number of toes he had. On the last day of camp, I was overjoyed – James was finally fitting in. Although the teasing hadn't entirely disappeared, James was speaking up and making friends. When he gave me one last hug and declared me his "bestest friend in the whole wide world," my heart swelled with pride. From my campers, I learned that working with children is incredibly rewarding. And from James, I learned that a little love can go a long way.

My Ye-Ye, a simple yet extraordinary person, has been a constant source of inspiration in my life. Despite facing immense hardship, he exudes joy and optimism. I idolize him, not because of his wealth or success, but because of his remarkable ability to find happiness in the face of adversity.

I vividly remember Ye-Ye's visit to our home seven years ago. He brought with him his signature red baseball cap, which became a staple in our household. Every night, it would sit on the stairway railing post, waiting to be placed back on his head the next morning. He wore it everywhere, performing magic tricks to make my little brother laugh, buying me popsicles, and wiping the sweat off my neck with it.

Today, whenever I see a red hat, I'm reminded of Ye-Ye's infectious smile and his zest for life. His story is a testament to the human spirit's ability to overcome adversity. Orphaned at a young age, Ye-Ye had to fend for himself and his brother, walking along railroad tracks to collect used coal to sell. He taught himself to read, write, and do arithmetic, and later worked in the harsh Gobi Desert for twelve hours a day.

Despite the challenges, Ye-Ye remained optimistic, always finding ways to make his family and others happy. He'd buy small luxuries for his children, like sunflower seeds and candy, and tell them stories of the desert sky. Even at the age of seventy-eight, Ye-Ye continues to spread joy, biking to the market to buy fresh fruits and vegetables, and sharing them with his neighbors.

Learning about Ye-Ye's past made me reevaluate my own life. I realized how trivial my worries were compared to his struggles. Now, whenever I face an obstacle, I think of Ye-Ye's smile and it gives me the strength to persevere.

I keep a red baseball cap at home, a reminder of Ye-Ye's spirit and the lessons he's taught me. It's a symbol of the impact he's had on my life, and I smile every time I see it.

The second part of the text seems to be a separate story about a camp experience. Here is a rewritten version of that part:

At camp, I met James, a camper who struggled to fit in due to his physical abnormalities. I was determined to help him feel more confident. One day, I impulsively hugged him, a gesture that surprised both of us. I looked him straight in the eye and told him that his external features didn't define him, and that as long as he was friendly, people would come around. I shared stories of successful individuals who had overcome their own challenges, and assured him that he would always be my favorite camper, no matter what.

By the end of camp, James was starting to find his place. Although the teasing hadn't completely stopped, he was speaking up and making friends. When he gave me a hug and called me his "bestest friend in the whole wide world," my heart swelled with pride. Working with children at camp taught me that a little love and kindness can go a long way in making a difference in someone's life.

Here is a rewritten version of the passage:

In the hazy stillness, a whirlwind of colorful skirts and whispered "Merde!"s erupts around me. I smooth my hair, a habitual gesture, though I know every strand is already in place. The stage lights above bathe my skin in warmth, and I wish their heat could seep into my brain, calming my frazzled nerves. Just then, a warm hand and an even warmer smile interrupt my anxious reverie. I glance up to see my lovely teacher, her nod coaxing a hesitant smile from my frozen lips. With a deep breath, my body takes its place, poised and ready. The music begins, and I count the beats: One, two, three, four; two, two, three, four.

As I step onto the stage, the lights and music envelop me. My lungs are on the verge of hyperventilating, but I focus on achieving a Zen-like state, imagining a field of daisies. Yet, my palms persist in sweating. It's not that I'm new to solo performances – I've had my share of piano recitals and competitions. But ballet demands a unique commitment of body and mind. I slide into an arabesque, leaning downward, careful not to stumble – Mom's recording every moment.

Despite my outgoing personality, a fear of failure has long held me back from taking risks. The prospect of leaping too high and falling too far has kept me grounded. As I've progressed in the cutthroat world of dance, this fear has only intensified, fueled by the pressure of greater expectations and the specter of greater embarrassment. But now, with every eye on me, I have a chance to break free. I glance toward the wings, where my teacher's exuberant gestures urge me to stretch further, to give more. A genuine smile replaces my forced enthusiasm, and I breathe in the music, forgetting individual steps. I allow myself to stretch, to leap, and to feel the jubilation of the moment.

Exhilarated and scared in the best way, I throw myself into my jumps. I no longer need to imagine scenes to get in the mood; the emotions are alive within me, twirling and leaping across the stage. Reaching, stretching, grabbing, flinging – my fear no longer holds me back. I rediscover my passion for ballet, and the grace and poise that can convey every color of emotion. Playing it safe will leave me in the shadows; only by taking risks can I step into the spotlight. Maybe I'll fall, but the rush is worth it. I'll captain a science bowl team, run a marathon, audition for a musical, and embrace the thrill of taking risks.

As I stood amidst the kaleidoscope of colors - red, orange, purple, and gold - I felt like I was caught in a whirlwind of shifting hues. I pranced up and down the hill, my palms outstretched to the fluttering butterflies that surrounded me. "Would you like to learn how to catch one?" Grandfather asked, holding out a glass jar. I exclaimed, "Yes!" and he carefully wrapped my chubby five-year-old hands around it with his huge, calloused fingers.

Grandfather put a finger to his lips, and I obediently watched as he skillfully maneuvered his net.
