He caught a magnificent butterfly perched on a flower, and I held the open jar in anticipation as he slid it inside. The butterfly quivered and fell to the bottom of the jar, and I gasped in wonder. It struggled until its wings, ablaze with a glory of orange and red, quivered to a stop. I watched, wide-eyed, as it stopped moving. "Grandpa, what's happening?" I asked.

My grandfather had always had a collection of butterflies, but that was the first time I saw him catch one. After witnessing the first butterfly die, I begged him to keep them alive; I even secretly set some free. To compromise, he began carrying a special jar on our outings, one that would keep the living butterflies alive. However, the creatures we caught always weakened and died after a few days in captivity, no matter how tenderly I fed and cared for them. Grandfather took me aside and explained that the lifespan of an adult butterfly was very short. They were not meant to live forever; their purpose was to shine brightly and then fade away. Thus, his art served as a memory of their beauty, an acknowledgment of nature's ephemeral splendor.

But nothing could stay the same. I moved to America, and as our weekly excursions to the mountainside ended, so did our lessons in nature and science. Although six thousand miles away, I would never forget how my grandpa's wrinkles creased when he smiled or how he always smelled like mountain flowers. As I grew older and slowly understood how Grandfather lived his life, I began to follow in his footsteps. He protected nature's beauty from decay with his art, and in the same way, I tried to protect my relationships, my artwork, and my memories.

I surrounded myself with the journals we wrote together, but this time I recorded my own accomplishments, hoping to one day show him what I had done. I recorded everything, from the first time I spent a week away from home to the time I received a gold medal at the top of the podium at the California Tae Kwon Do Competition. I filled my new home in America with the photographs from my childhood and began to create art of my own. Instead of catching butterflies like my grandpa, I began experimenting with butterfly wing art as my way of preserving nature's beauty. Soon my home in America became a replica of my home in China, filled from wall to wall with pictures and memories.

Nine long years passed before I was reunited with him. The robust man who once chased me up the hillside had developed arthritis, and his thick black hair had turned white. The grandfather I saw now was not the one I knew; we had no hobby and no history in common, and he became another adult, distant and unapproachable. With this, I forgot all about the journals and photos that I had kept and wanted to share with him. After weeks of avoidance, I gathered my courage and sat with him once again. This time, I carried a large, leather-bound book with me.

"Grandfather," I began, and held out the first of my many journals. These were my early days in America, chronicled through pictures, art, and neatly-printed English. On the last page was a photograph of me and my grandfather, a net in his hand and a jar in mine. As I saw our faces, shining with proud smiles, I began to remember our days on the mountainside, catching butterflies and halting nature's eventual decay. My grandfather has weakened over the years, but he is still the wise man who raised me and taught me the value of capturing the beauty of life. Although he has grown old, I have grown up. His legs are weak, but his hands are still as gentle as ever. Therefore, this time, it will be different. This time, I will no longer recollect memories, but create new ones.

As I took the stage, I felt a surge of excitement. "Lean extra in this pirouette; it's more aesthetic," I reminded myself. But is it always better to be safe than sorry? Glancing toward the wings, I saw my teacher's wild gesticulations: "Stretch your arms out, she seems to mime, More!" A genuine smile replaced one of forced enthusiasm; alone on the stage, this was my chance to shine. I breathed in the movements, forgot each individual step. More than just imagining, but finally experiencing the jubilation of the music, I allowed my splits to stretch across the stage and my steps to extend longer and longer, until I was no longer safe and my heart was racing.

Exhilarated and scared in the best way, I threw myself into my jumps. I no longer needed to imagine scenes to get in the mood; the emotions were twirling and leaping within me. Reaching, stretching, grabbing, flinging... My fear no longer shields me. I found my old passion for ballet, and remembered the grace and poise that can nevertheless convey every color of emotion. Playing it safe will leave me part of the backdrop; only by taking risks can I step into the limelight. Maybe I'll fall, but the rush is worth it. I'll captain an all-male science bowl team, run a marathon, audition for a musical, and embrace the physical and intellectual elation of taking risks.

Here is a rewritten version of the passage:

I collapsed onto my parents' bed, overcome with emotion, my head buried in my knees. "Why did you have to do that to me?" I sobbed. "Why did you have to show me that house and then take it away?" In desperation, I turned to God, my last resort. For years, my family and I had been nomads, moving from country to country in search of a better life. War and lack of educational opportunities had driven my parents to pack up and embark on a new journey, taking us from Kuçovë, Albania, to Athens, Greece, and finally to Boston, Massachusetts. Despite always having a roof over our heads, I had never had a place to call my own. That night, as I prayed, my mind flashed back to the evening I had stumbled upon the listing for the house. It was September 22, 2007 – exactly eight years since we had arrived in the United States. I knew it was fate that had brought this house to me. I remembered visiting the yellow house the next day with my parents and falling deeply in love with it. But I also remembered the crushing phone call that had come later that week, telling us that the owners had chosen another family's offer. A week after I had prayed, I had given up hope of ever owning that house. But then, one day after school, I walked into our small apartment and saw the flashing red light on the phone. I clicked PLAY and was shocked to hear our real estate agent's joyful voice on the other end. "Eda! The deal fell through with the other family – the house is yours! Call me back immediately to start the paperwork." I stood there, stunned, replaying the words in my head. Was this really happening? Was my dream of owning a home finally coming true? Over the next month, I spent my days at school and my afternoons making phone calls, navigating the complex process of buying a home. Although my parents struggled with English, I was determined to help make this dream a reality. So, instead of gossiping with friends about makeup or boys, my conversations were filled with terms like "fixed-rate mortgages" and "down payments." I was determined to help purchase this home, to give my family the sense of belonging I had always lacked. For thirteen years, I had felt ashamed of our small apartment, unable to host sleepovers or gossip with friends about our rooms. But now, I had the chance to change that. A home, to me, is more than just four walls and a roof – it's a place filled with laughter and memories, where my family can feel safe and loved. No matter where life takes me, I know that I will always have a yellow home, filled with love, waiting for me.

As I crocheted, the white yarn slipped off my aluminum hook, adding a single crochet to the rows of existing stitches that resembled a blob. I stared at the image of the little unicorn amigurumi on my laptop screen, then looked back at the UMO (unidentified messy object) in front of me, feeling utterly perplexed. This was supposed to be easy. I had followed the pattern: Round 1, create a magic circle with 6 single crochets - done. Round 2, increase to 12 stitches - also done. But the remaining rounds had blurred into hours and minutes, resulting in a tangled mess of white yarn instead of a little white unicorn. It wasn't until day seven that a creature with a lopsided head and a distinctive horn finally emerged.

Similarly, my journey to find my passion and forge my own path had been confusing, messy, and at times infuriating. I had heard stories of people finding their passion at a young age and exceling in their craft, others who abandoned their interests for a lucrative career, and those who pursued their dreams only to regret it later. These stories weighed heavily on me, as I was determined to have a success story like many of my family members. The problem was, I didn't have a direction.

In the years following primary school, I tried to find my passion by stepping out of my comfort zone and joining various activities: the school orchestra, debate class, and ballet school, where I explored contemporary and jazz dance. I accumulated experiences like an amigurumi stuffed with batting, but soon found myself overwhelmed by extracurriculars. I still felt lost, like I was drowning in a sea of tangled yarn.

It wasn't until high school that I realized I could view my mission to find a passion from a different perspective. Completing a crochet project is an accomplishment in itself, but the process of making slip knots, single or double crochets, takes you on an adventure. The knots I encountered in my craft were evidence of my experiences and what shaped me as an individual. My exploration of various paths, though sometimes resulting in roadblocks, taught me to persevere and learn from my experiences, applying the skills I gained to future challenges. The mini adventures I went on were crucial to my greater journey in life.

Through trial and error, I've found that my current adventure in service and environmental activism resonates with me the most. However, I've learned that no one path is static, and I can be on multiple paths at once. While I may not have achieved the proportionate unicorn amigurumi that others may have, I still have so much to learn and want to learn, and so my journey to grow continues.

If someone had told me at the age of 11 that I would one day be playing a sport called squash, I would have thought they were crazy. But when I entered seventh grade at a new school that was ten times larger than my previous one, I felt like a small fish in a big pond. I was quiet, introverted, and often stuck to what was familiar. During the first week of school, a group of visitors introduced themselves as Squashbusters, a program that combined the sport of squash with academic support, mentoring, and service opportunities. Although I had only heard of squash once before, I was intrigued by the program's unique approach and decided to sign up. That decision has made a profound impact on my life over the past six years.

As a part of Squashbusters, I was pushed out of my comfort zone and encouraged to challenge myself in ways I never thought possible. The program's emphasis on pushing past our limits on the squash court translated to other areas of my life, and I began to take on new challenges with confidence. From team trips and tournaments to karaoke nights and quirky traditions like our annual Squashbusters Olympics, I gradually expanded my comfort zone. My peers brought out a side of me I never knew existed, and while I haven't transformed from an introvert to an extrovert, I have become more social and confident over the years.

As I prepare to join the Hopkins community, I am excited to continue this journey of self-discovery and growth. I want to try new things, embrace campus traditions, and explore beyond my comfort zone. While I am eager to develop intellectually through Hopkins' academic classes and clubs, I believe that true community is built by venturing beyond what we're used to. From Blue Jay Opening Day and the Spring Fair to clubs like Amnesty International and the Foreign Affairs Symposium, I am thrilled by the limitless opportunities to get involved and make a difference at Hopkins. I am excited to be a part of the Hopkins family and contribute to a community that values growth, exploration, and innovation.

Here is a rewritten version of the passage:

As I walked in the door from school, my grandmother greeted me with a familiar phrase: "Bring up the ace of spades." We settled in for our daily game of solitaire, working together in harmony to reorganize the cards with precision. Though solitaire was meant to be a solo activity, it was the one thing we did together, moving and dealing the cards in a rhythmic dance of order: red to black, red to black. For hours, we sat at our glossy kitchen table, playing game after game, pulling patterns out of the random array of cards.

I often wondered why we had to follow the rules so strictly. Why not just take a peek at the cards or "help ourselves" to win? But my grandmother was adamant about adhering to the traditional rules, even when it meant losing. One day, after a particularly frustrating loss, I asked her why we played this way. She looked at me with her deep brown eyes and said, "Solitaire isn't just a game for one person. It's a battle between two sides of yourself. If one side cheats, how can either side improve?"

At first, I didn't understand. But as I watched her effortlessly move the cards with her frail hands, I began to see the wisdom in her words. Solitaire was a metaphor for life - a constant struggle to improve, to push oneself harder, and to resist the temptation to take the easy way out.

Years later, I found myself drawing on this lesson in various aspects of my life. On the field hockey pitch, I realized I had been cheating myself and my team by not giving my all. While helping my parents with household chores, I saw the value in not taking shortcuts. And in the pottery studio, I discovered the satisfaction of creating something beautiful through hard work and dedication.

Looking back, I realize that my grandmother's lesson has been a guiding force in my life. It's a reminder to always hold myself accountable, to work hard, and to resist the temptation to cheat. As I lay out the seven columns, four aces, and fifty-two cards, I'm transported back to those afternoons playing solitaire with my grandmother. Her inner strength and resilience in the face of adversity continue to inspire me, and I'm grateful for the lesson she taught me that day.

"Don't be so hasty, Dante," my chess coach advised. "Take a step back, think critically, and examine the entire board." I was stumped, convinced that I had solved the intricate chess puzzle. But what was I missing? A knight fork, perhaps, or a bishop's clever move? Was I in check? A quick glance at the left side of the board revealed my mistake: my queen was idle, positioned on the opposite side of the board, and I had no idea. Sacrificing my queen would force the opposing rook to capture it, allowing me to checkmate with the elegant "smothered mate." This lesson stuck with me: looking at the whole board made chess puzzles manageable. My chess skills improved rapidly, and my rating soared above 1000 Elo in just a few months.

However, this lesson extended far beyond the chessboard. It became a foundational skill that I applied to various aspects of my life, including school and sports. On the soccer field, I was no powerhouse, weighing in at 125 pounds and standing 5'8". My opponents often tackled me to the ground. But one day, as I lay dazed on the pitch, I recalled my chess lesson. Soccer, like chess, relies on the strategic positioning of each player to create a cohesive strategy. It's not just about speed, strength, or tackles; it's about understanding the game and making smart decisions. I realized that my greatest asset was my in-depth knowledge of the game – knowing where to pass, when to make a run, and how to outmaneuver my opponents. I picked myself up, focused on the game, and chipped the ball into open space behind the defender, trusting my teammate to follow. From then on, I honed my skills through intense practice, working in tandem with my teammates to become a well-balanced, unified team.

Through chess and soccer, I learned that every piece in a puzzle has a purpose. This new perspective has enhanced my ability to stop, reflect, and analyze the bigger picture in various dimensions of my life. In my scientific studies, I learned to zoom out and examine the entire scope of quorum sensing, rather than focusing on a single cell. In music, I discovered that the true beauty of a composition lies in the harmony of all instruments, not just the melody. These facets of my life – music, research, soccer, chess – are not isolated puzzles but interconnected parts of a greater whole. Every aspect of myself matters equally. As high school comes to a close, the pieces on my board are set, and I'm poised for success. Your move.

As a student pilot, I learned a valuable lesson: left and right are relative terms that don't apply when you're soaring 36,000 feet in the air at nearly 200 miles per hour. On the ground, these directions might be sufficient for navigating highways and parking lots, but in the air, they're woefully inadequate. During one of my early flights in a small Cessna-182, my instructor tasked me with scanning the horizon for approaching aircraft. I spotted a plane to my right, a Cessna with maroon stripes, its windows glinting in the sunlight. I gestured vaguely to my two o'clock and informed my instructor, "There's a plane to the right." But he corrected me, "No, to your right. From his perspective, what direction does he see you?" I realized that from his angle, I was to his left. In that moment, I understood the importance of perspective and precise language.

As I navigated through the skies using my compass's north, east, south, and west directions, I came to appreciate that every pilot's vantage point differs, creating opposing perspectives. My right was that pilot's left. This realization sparked a newfound appreciation for considering multiple viewpoints, regardless of my personal perspective. Perhaps it was this ability to scan the horizon and communicate a single story, uniting contrasting outlooks, that drew me to journalism and the diverse community that was my home.

To me, journalism embodies the ancient power of storytelling, filled with imperfect characters and intricate conflicts, where I serve as the narrator. As editor-in-chief of my school newspaper, The Wildcat's Tale, I strive to share the uncensored perspectives of all students and encourage my editorial team to engage with those who hold differing opinions. We begin each edition with a round-table discussion, exploring questions like "why did this happen" and "where will it lead?" By expanding my reach to publications like the Korea Daily and the Los Angeles Times High School Insider, I've had the opportunity to interview city council candidates, voters of all ages, and mayors, weaving their quotes and anecdotes into my writing. My experiences have taught me to report on polarizing opinions through an unbiased lens, recognizing that I cannot presume my readers' opinions, but rather provide them with the tools to form their own conclusions.

In my writing, I've discovered that differences in perspective aren't limited to politics. I've found that my community craves stories about the small-town hospitality of their friends and neighbors. Quirky traditions, like our Fourth of July carnival clown and local elementary school's Thanksgiving talent show, are just as important to me as national headlines. My favorite stories to publish are those that resonate with readers, proudly displayed on fridges, in diners, or on classroom corkboards. I've learned that the impact I leave on my readers matters more than the size of my story. Through flying and writing, I've come to appreciate the importance of embracing diverse perspectives, recognizing that living life with blinders can be not only boring but also dangerous. Whether I'm soaring through the skies or reporting on the ground, I've discovered that the most compelling stories come from the people most different from me.

"I'm not a dancer, or so I thought. In reality, I'm surprisingly inept when it comes to executing even the simplest dance moves. My grandmother often laments my lack of rhythm, describing it as a 'tragedy' to watch me struggle with our traditional West African dances. Yet, I still take to the dance floor at family gatherings, seemingly oblivious to my limitations. Eventually, my embarrassing display prompts someone to intervene and teach me the correct steps. What's astonishing is that, despite my initial claim of being unable to dance, I've been performing choreographed routines at my school's pep rallies for the past three years. Reflecting on these experiences has made me realize that my initial statement was a misrepresentation. I can dance, but only when I'm willing to collaborate with others. My ability to dance is directly tied to my willingness to work with others, and I've come to value community and collaboration greatly. 

Through my internship at the Johns Hopkins Applied Physics Lab, I was exposed to the collaborative spirit that defines Johns Hopkins. The idea that innovation and discovery are impossible without teamwork was reinforced during my research. I've come to see that mutual collaboration and community are essential aspects of Johns Hopkins' unique culture. From research initiatives that bridge the gap between class levels to organizations like the Tutorial Project, which relies on students working together to make a positive impact on Baltimore, and the access to interdisciplinary topics like neuromorphic systems, I believe that Johns Hopkins represents the pinnacle of collaborative achievement in education."

I made some changes to improve clarity, coherence, and sentence structure. I also tried to preserve the original tone and voice of the text. Let me know if you have any specific requests or if you'd like me to revise anything!

Growing up, I had one wish that wasn't about getting something, but about having someone - a sibling. I would often envy my friends who had brothers and sisters to play with, feeling stuck at home alone with my parents. But everything changed when my parents brought home my new sister, Mia - a furry Lhasa Apso dog. Although she wasn't the human sibling I had dreamed of, Mia helped me appreciate being an only child.

However, it took me much longer to come to terms with feeling alone in other ways. Living in a predominantly white town and attending a school with a mostly white student body had a profound impact on my sense of identity as a Filipino. I would secretly eat the traditional adobo chicken my mom packed for lunch, while my friends had turkey and cheese sandwiches. I stood by as my classmates made jokes about Asians, and I felt like my heritage was something to be ashamed of. In social studies classes, I learned more about my friends' ancestry than my own.

I started to believe that assimilation was the key to acceptance, and that it was the only way to feel less alone. I masked the aromas of Filipino delicacies with pasta and hamburgers when my friends came over, laughed off incidents of mistaken identity, and accepted that learning about European and East Asian history was the norm.

But everything changed when I entered high school. Although the student body wasn't more diverse in terms of ethnicity, I was surrounded by open-minded, politically and culturally active students. Through electives, clubs, and activities, I was exposed to a wide range of perspectives. I met students from around the world at speech and debate tournaments, and engaged in lively discussions with the High School Democrats Club and Young Conservatives Club.

For the first time, I felt confident in my Filipino identity. I introduced my friends to Filipino dishes like lumpia and toron, asked my social studies teachers about the history and current state of the Philippines, and stopped seeing my background as a source of loneliness. Instead, I embraced it as what made me unique.

I changed my narrative from "alone" to "unique," and I strive to spread the message that being different is something to be celebrated. I wouldn't be who I am without my Filipino background, and although my community initially made me feel alone, it also gave me the opportunity to learn, grow, and appreciate what makes me special.

Here is a rewritten version of the passage:

As I navigated my tough transition, I wasn't expecting Ms. McVaugh's unconventional offer: to join a girls' field hockey practice. At first, I was taken aback, but as I imagined lacing up my field hockey cleats again, a surge of excitement coursed through my veins. The next day, as I stepped onto the turf, my initial anxiety resurfaced. I felt like all eyes were on me, and I could almost hear the girls thinking, "Boys don't play field hockey." As I trailed behind during the warm-up, the silence was deafening, and quitting seemed more tempting by the second. But when the whistle blew, something remarkable happened. The gender barrier vanished, and I saw a shared passion in the girls' red faces and heard the emotion in their cheers. By the end of practice, I was overcome with joy, my body aglow as I caught my breath on the bench. In that moment, I realized that I shouldn't let obstacles like gender boundaries hold me back from exploring new opportunities. Embracing the unconventional had brought me joy, and I decided to apply this mindset to the soccer field, focusing on the beauty of the sport rather than worrying about playing time or titles. Within days, the same electric atmosphere transferred to the soccer field, and I began to absorb feedback, ask questions, and try new skills. As I improved, I grasped the value of my new approach. I took this open, curious, and risk-taking mindset into the classroom, asking deeper questions to understand new material, and into the dorm, where I turned cultural differences into opportunities to learn and contribute. From mastering nucleophile-electrophile reactions to sharing Dutch treats with my hall, these moments reminded me why I had sacrificed my field hockey gear to attend Deerfield. Even as I achieved the grades, friendships, and athletic successes I had sought, I realized that I valued the exploration, growth, and joy behind those successes far more. Now, before I take the field, enter the classroom, or step into my dorm, I don't worry about what I might fail to achieve or the obstacles that might hold me back. Instead, I pour my heart into these opportunities, embracing the experiences they bring.

The Oreo cookie, with its firm chocolate exterior and creamy white center, holds a surprising significance for me. Unbeknownst to me, this simple treat was tied to a social stigma that left a lingering bad taste in my mouth. As a lover of both ballroom and pop music, I've always found myself lost in the stories woven by each note. From the sultry tango melodies to the upbeat Top 40 hits, I've been drawn to the vastly different styles since I was a little girl listening to Hans Zimmer's "Discombobulate" and One Direction's "Kiss You". However, when I shared my musical tastes with my black peers in high school, I was met with confused stares. "Faith, that's so white of you," a friend exclaimed. "You're such an Oreo!" I didn't understand the connection between Oreos and racial identity until I later learned that being an "Oreo" meant being a black person who adopted characteristics typically associated with white people, thereby "betraying" their black roots.

I never thought of ballroom and pop music as belonging to a particular race, but the negative connotations of "betrayal" introduced a new sense of guilt. Should I embrace my musical interests and risk social alienation from those who share my skin tone? Or should I set aside my "white" tastes and conform to the expectations of an African-American woman? I didn't abandon music altogether. As a clarinet player in my school band, I was exposed to various styles daily. During my freshman year, I decided to challenge myself by performing a solo for the county solo and ensemble festival. Lyrical Composition No. 6 was a piece I could technically master, but my band director pushed me to go beyond mere technicality. "Where's your interpretation? What can you add to this piece?" At first, I saw only the fixed, unyielding notes on the page. How could I contribute to a composition that seemed so definitive?

Then I looked beyond the measures, beyond the notes, and saw the blank white space waiting for my input. I realized that I needed to decide what I wanted the audience to feel from this composition. With pencil in hand, I added crescendos, decrescendos, breath marks, and other markings that I felt were necessary. I didn't want to simply regurgitate the notes; I wanted to take the audience on a dynamic journey. This realization clarified the distinction between style and stereotype. Being labeled an Oreo was jarring because the documented definition couldn't be erased. Most stereotypes are deeply ingrained in societal views of certain races. While I can't change the minds of others, I can change my own.

I am my own music maker. I will celebrate the intricacies of ballroom music and belt out a One Direction tune as a proud black woman. That is my style. That is my choice of expression. If allowed, stereotypes can consume me, but I refuse to be held down by their grip. I decide my definition of the black experience. My musical interests are not a betrayal that isolates me from my roots; they're a beautiful addition that enhances my ever-evolving character. Am I an Oreo? Yes, but by my own design. The creamy white center no longer represents a betrayal; it's a blank canvas waiting for my input. With pencil in hand, I will not hesitate to make my mark.

As I clutched the math packet, I could still hear my teacher's words echoing in my mind: "This is a challenge. But I think you're up for it." The title "Mission Possible!" on the cover seemed to leap out at me, its black italicized letters radiating an air of mystery. I felt a thrill of excitement, my fingers tingling and goosebumps rising on my arms. As I walked home, I couldn't help but stare at the title, sensing that it held secrets waiting to be unlocked.

As soon as I got home, I rushed to my top bunk, grabbed a pencil, and made a mental pact with the packet: "I, Zerubabel, promise to prioritize you, put you above all else in my life, not rest, and not eat until all the problems that lay in your pages are solved." Looking back, I was a dramatic 11-year-old, but that experience was just one example of the many challenges I've faced throughout my life.

My love for challenges and my tenacious approach to them were instilled in me through observing my family and my own experiences. Ten years ago, my family and I made the bold decision to leave everything behind and start anew in America. During our first year in Minnesota, we faced the daunting challenge of financial struggle. My sister had to share a bed with my mom and me, while my dad slept on a makeshift bed every night. My mom worked tirelessly, waking up early and staying up late, both at home and at her minimum wage job. Despite the difficulties, my parents never complained, viewing it as just another stage of life to overcome.

Through their hard work and perseverance, our living situation gradually improved. One bed became two, and eventually, each of us had our own bed to sleep on. Reflecting on this experience and many others, I realize that it was through observing my parents' unwavering dedication that I learned the value of perseverance, my mom's commitment to her job that taught me the value of devotion, my dad's pursuit of better opportunities that instilled in me the value of ambition, and my sister's willingness to make sacrifices that showed me the value of selflessness.

Through my own experiences, I learned that I could apply these values to overcome any challenge that came my way. After two grueling months of working on the packet, I finally finished with all the questions answered. This sense of accomplishment fueled my ambition, leading me to take the most challenging courses available in middle and high school. In my community, my commitment to serving at my church for the past five years has been a testament to the values instilled in me.

These values have shaped me into the person I am today and will continue to guide me as I pursue my goals in life. It is because of these values and the people who first demonstrated them to me that I have decided to pursue a career as a surgeon. I am confident that with the guidance of these values, I will be able to achieve my goal.

My Chuck Taylor sneakers, officially M7652-000, were meant to be a vibrant yellow. But after years of wear and tear, they've accumulated a rich patina of dirt, guitar chords, and conversations. When I first moved to Houston in eighth grade, I tried to fit in by keeping my shoes spotless. However, as I navigated the complexities of adolescence, I realized that embracing my individuality and listening to diverse perspectives was far more important.

As I grew, my shoes became a canvas for the people and experiences that shaped me. On the right inner canvas, "Cheyenne yo yo" is scrawled, a testament to my friendship with Cheyenne, whom I met through freshman year volleyball. Initially, we bonded over superficial commonalities, but it was our differences that ultimately brought us closer. She challenged me to think critically and form my own opinions, unswayed by my background or parents.

In Portland, where I'm from, opinions are freely expressed, and in Houston, where I moved, the cultural landscape was vastly different. Instead of liberal bumper stickers, I encountered conservative sentiments like "Come and Take It." Initially, I struggled to adapt, but by sophomore year, I realized that compromising my values to fit in was a mistake. I began to express my opinions openly, and in doing so, I discovered a sense of purpose.

My left shoe is a treasure trove of memories, featuring meme references, song lyrics, sketches of NASA star clusters, and Italian phrases. It's also where I've inscribed "Lorrie Lake Ln.," a nod to the late-night discussions and debates I've had with friends at Sandalwood, a polluted lake that's become a symbol of our collective angst and existential questions.

Through my relationships, I've learned to appreciate the value of disagreement. I've discovered that Mormons don't drink coffee, and Romanians feast on an entire pig during winter. Their philosophies, though often at odds with mine, have taught me the importance of listening to opposing views.

When I first moved to Texas, I felt suffocated by the Kinkaid bubble, but I soon realized that I didn't have to conform to enjoy life. Embracing the contradictions and dissonances in my life has allowed me to grow more into myself, becoming more open-minded and educated about the world.

In college, where self-discovery is a rite of passage, I know I can bring a unique perspective to the table. My life is a playlist of contradictions, and I'm proud to be a conduit for diversity of thought, inspiring others to embrace the beauty of listening to the other side.

Here is a rewritten version of the passage:

On a sweltering summer night, in the heart of Boston's TD Garden, I formed an instant bond with 19,580 strangers. We had all converged on this iconic venue to witness the legendary Tom Petty perform live. His music was a shared thread that connected us all, a common language that transcended our individual experiences. I had grown up listening to his songs, introduced to them by my mother, and they held a special place in my heart. But as I looked around the room, I realized that his music meant something unique to each person present, a kaleidoscope of emotions and memories that harmonized with the rhythm of the music.

As I closed my eyes, I could feel the collective heartbeat of the crowd, pulsating in time with the music. It was as if Tom Petty's art had given me a profound awareness of the lives and emotions of those around me. In that moment, I understood that his music would live on, long after he was gone, because it had become an integral part of our collective experience.

As I gazed out at the sea of smiling faces, dancing arms, and carefree spirits, I realized that we were all feeling something deeply personal, yet shared. We were all connected, bound together by our emotions, despite our individual struggles and challenges. Tom Petty's music had created a sense of community, a sense of belonging that transcended time and space.

I long to make connections with others, to understand their experiences and emotions, and to find common ground. Music, art, and storytelling have become my tools for bridging the gaps between people. I sit at my piano, lost in the rhythm and melody, trying to capture the essence of the human experience. I collect the art of others, staring at paintings until they seem to stare back at me, and I cry at films that touch my heart.

Art, to me, is a reflection of our collective humanity, a manifestation of empathy and understanding. It allows us to see the world from different perspectives, to walk in others' shoes, and to connect with their emotions. Tom Petty's music, like all great art, is a testament to the power of human connection, a reminder that we are not alone in our struggles and triumphs.

As I navigate my daily commute, I use music as a catalyst for conversation, a way to break down barriers and connect with strangers. I talk to my neighbors about our shared love of music, and suddenly, we're no longer strangers. My dad, once distant, becomes closer when we bond over our love of The Band. These are the moments that make life worth living, the moments that remind us that we are all connected, and that art is the thread that weaves us together.

As a child, I had a peculiar dream job: driving a giant pickle truck. I was captivated by the idea after seeing it in Richard Scarry's "Cars and Trucks and Things That Go." My parents would read the book to me and my sister every night, and I'd search for the hidden golden bug, Goldbug, on every page. I'd imagine myself as a pig driving the pickle truck across the country, chasing Goldbug. As I grew older, my ambitions shifted: I wanted to be a Lego Master, then an architect, and eventually a surgeon. But when I discovered gold nanoparticles that could reprogram macrophages to fight cancer, my passion for nanomedicine was ignited. I devoured articles on liposomes, polymeric micelles, and dendrimers, all of which seemed to hold the key to conquering cancer.

I sought out a mentor to guide me deeper into the field and was thrilled to work with Dr. Sangeeta Ray at Johns Hopkins. In her lab, I was given the autonomy to design and implement my own procedures. I chose to tackle a pressing issue in nanomedicine: the consistent failure of nanoparticles to translate from animal studies to clinical trials. I created three novel constructs based on different linear polymers, each using fluorescent dye, to test whether a pre-dose of a common chemotherapeutic could enhance nanoparticle delivery in aggressive prostate cancer. Although I didn't expect my hypothesis to work, I was thrilled to find that cyclophosphamide did indeed increase nanoparticle delivery to the tumor in a statistically significant way.

Beyond the research, I discovered a new passion: sharing my findings with others. Living alone in Baltimore, I formed unexpected friendships with graduate school students from the lab, and we explored the city together. I realized that making others interested in science was more exciting to me than the research itself. This epiphany solidified my pursuit to use writing to illuminate science in a way that's accessible to everyone, adding value to a society that needs more scientific literacy.

As I reflect on my journey, I'm reminded that my goals are still evolving. In Scarry's book, there's a goldbug on every page, and I've come to realize that it's not the destination that matters, but the act of searching for the goldbugs that will shape and refine my passions. Regardless of where my journey takes me, I know that my pickle truck has only just begun its journey.

Every Tuesday and Thursday, I spend my time on the farm, digging in the soil to remove crab grass and borage. I've been a farmer since my sophomore year, working on a one-acre plot that's more like a garden with chickens, managed by my school. Today, my task is to harvest cherry tomatoes, most of which have ripened to perfection. I grab a tray from the shed and walk along the pathways I created during my junior year, lined with wood chips that I raked into place. Our two tomato vines are thriving, standing three feet tall and stretching out at least six feet, laden with small, glistening red and orange spheres. As I work, I fall into a rhythm, plucking and collecting the tomatoes, snacking on a few as I go. I'm reminded of when I was six, and my mom would send my twin brother and me to the backyard to weed dandelions. We'd get distracted and play with our dog or climb the dogwood tree. I think back to the awe I felt last week when I harvested a giant sunflower, discovering ten potatoes growing in its roots, or when I found a sweet potato the size of a football, which I had planted the previous year. I ponder the jalapenos, whose scratches indicate their level of spiciness. I recall the satisfaction I felt the first time I ate a raw green bean I grew at the farm, and the pleasure I feel knowing that friends and teachers also enjoy the produce we donate to the school's dining hall and sell at the weekly farmer's market. After my farm shift, I'll work at the market, ready to answer questions about the farm's location, its workers, and what we do with unsold food. Sometimes, I think about the farmers I met in Yangshuo, China, who rely solely on farming to feed their families, and how the difference between one and two dollars for pomelos means the world to them. As I carry my share of tomatoes to the shed, I reflect on how much the farm has taught me. I can't sit down to a meal without imagining the plants on my plate as seeds and sprouts, and wondering about the many hands that brought them to my table. To me, education means understanding the hidden processes that make up daily life. Playing with the farm chickens and knowing how the coating around an egg works as a natural preservative makes me appreciate my omelet more. Watching weeds decompose into fertilizer in the compost pile makes me consider the roles of carbon and nitrogen cycles. Although I initially joined the farm to try something new, I quickly found that the work offers a balance with the intellectual work of the rest of my day. The farm connects education with experience, teaching me to see the application of my classroom learning in a real setting. This connection piques my curiosity and inspires me to maintain it throughout my life, contributing to my community in meaningful ways, locally and globally. I will seek out opportunities to cultivate soil and use my learning to see and understand more of the world.

Every day, I'm on the lookout for women with permanent art that tells a story. My math teacher, a Starbucks barista, and a customer at my workplace have all caught my attention with their unique tattoos. I'm fascinated by the quotes, dates, symbols, and abstract shapes that adorn their bodies, and I've started asking them questions to uncover the stories behind their ink. This informal interviewing process has become a daily scavenger hunt, inspiring me with the individuality and diversity of the women I meet.

Without the constraints of a school assignment or deadline, I've been able to engage in meaningful conversations with these women, exploring the significance of their tattoos and the impact they've had on their lives. So far, I've conducted fifteen interviews with women from all walks of life, from teenagers to senior citizens, and from teachers to spiritual healers. These conversations have been eye-opening, with women sharing stories about overcoming struggles, finding strength, and embracing their identities.

Through these interviews, I've discovered that tattoos can be a powerful form of self-expression, revealing aspects of a person's personality, values, and experiences. I've learned about the complex relationship between the personal and public spheres, and how tattoos can be both a form of empowerment and a source of vulnerability. The stories I've heard have also taught me about the art of storytelling and the importance of active listening.

As I continue this project in college, I'm excited to gather more stories and showcase the strength, creativity, and diversity of the women I've met. By exploring the art and stories behind their tattoos, I hope to inspire others to embrace their individuality and to foster greater understanding and empathy. Ultimately, this project has taught me that with an open mind and a willingness to explore, even the simplest idea can become a meaningful and impactful reality.

"I confidently assert, 'Biogeochemical - it's a word, I swear!' The room erupts in a cacophony of shrieks and shouts, both in support and protest. Insults fly, and credentials are questioned, with even a piece of my grandmother's flaky paratha whizzing past my ear. Too lazy to consult a dictionary or even their phones, we engage in a heated debate. In the end, I emerge victorious, basking in the glory of being the champion of the Merchant household. However, my triumph is short-lived, as the glossy plastic tiles that formed my winning word are swept away and mixed with the rejected tiles, setting the stage for our next game of Bananagrams. The next round is just as intense, with my father arguing that 'Rambo' is a legitimate word (it's not). Communication and words have always been crucial in my life, from playful games like Bananagrams and our favorite road-trip pastime, to the challenges of conversing with grandparents who speak different Indian languages. Whether it's trying to understand the cheesemonger's southern drawl, crafting a script to elicit laughter, or combining flavors in a recipe, words hold immense power and influence. They can evoke laughter, tears, and a range of emotions. The idea that a single word can contribute to a larger concept, much like the intricate biogeochemical cycles, is truly remarkable. After our spirited games, my family quickly regains its composure, gathering around steaming bowls of my grandmother's rice and cumin-spiced chicken (food is always at the heart of our gatherings). As we enjoy our meal, our words transform from aggressive banter to lighthearted jokes and affectionate concerns about each other's well-being."

The phrase "You're such a hipster" is a common refrain in American high schools, but it's a label that can be both empowering and confounding. I know this from personal experience. Since my pre-teen years, I've had an innate desire to stand out from the crowd, to reject the status quo. In middle school, this manifested in my fashion choices, musical tastes, and literary interests. As I entered high school, I felt a sense of pride in being different and a passion for exploring new ways to express myself.

However, as I delved deeper into the world of nonconformity, I stumbled upon a subculture that was often associated with the term "hipster." This subculture was defined by its fashion trends and musical genres, and its adherents were known for their strong nonconformist tendencies. I was drawn to this subculture and began to adopt its aesthetic, donning beanies and cardigans, and filling my iPod with Bon Iver and The Smiths. But as I did, I started to receive attention from my peers, both positive and negative, in the form of the very phrase that had become so ubiquitous: "You're such a hipster!"

At first, the attention was exhilarating, and I found myself obsessed with maintaining my "hipster" reputation. But as time went on, I realized that I was conforming to a certain standard, rather than staying true to myself. I was asking myself how I could fit the ideal, rather than who I wanted to be. This was the paradox at the heart of the "hipster" label: on the one hand, it celebrated individuality and nonconformity, but on the other hand, it required adherents to conform to a certain set of norms.

It took me months of struggle and self-reflection to realize that the problem wasn't with the qualities associated with being a "hipster," but with letting a label define my identity. I had to figure out who I was, free from outside influence, before I could apply any adjectives to my character. The solution was not to reject the "hipster" label outright, but to understand that it was just one aspect of my personality, and that I was more than just a label.

I had never broken into a car before, but that's exactly what I found myself doing in Laredo, Texas, after a long day of volunteering at a Habitat for Humanity work site. Our group had finished their first day, and the Hotchkiss volunteers had left to enjoy some Texas BBQ, leaving me and the college kids to clean up. But as we were about to leave, we realized we were locked out of the van. Someone rummaged through a dumpster, pulled out a coat hanger, and handed it to me, suggesting I try to unlock the door. I was skeptical, but I gave it a shot. To my surprise, after a few minutes of jiggling the hanger around the window frame, the lock clicked open.

As I succeeded in breaking into the van, I had a sudden realization: I had been in this type of situation before. In fact, I was born into it. Growing up in a family of seven, I was accustomed to unpredictability and chaos. My home was always loud, messy, and spottily supervised. My siblings argued, the dog barked, and the phone rang - all part of a normal day. My dad, a retired Navy pilot, was often away, and when he was home, he ruled with a firm hand. At the age of nine, he taught me how to clear burning oil from the surface of water, a lesson that may not have been practical but drove home the point that life is full of unexpected twists and turns.

Living in my family taught me to roll with reality, negotiate on the fly, and attempt the improbable. I learned not to sweat the small stuff and not to expect perfect fairness. When our dining room table only had six chairs for seven people, someone learned to be on time every night. But more importantly, I learned to thrive in situations beyond my control. I learned to adapt, to forge alliances, and to realign them as necessary. Sometimes I was the vulnerable little brother, and sometimes I was the wise elder. I learned to be different things to different people, depending on the situation.

This fall, our Head of School asked us a question that resonated deeply with me: "How can I participate in a thing I do not govern, in the company of people I did not choose?" It was a question that echoed the one I had faced in Laredo. And I knew the answer. I knew why the coat hanger had been handed to me. Growing up in my family, I was a vital participant in a thing I did not govern, in the company of people I did not choose. It's family, it's society, and often, it's chaos. You participate by letting go of the small stuff, not expecting order and perfection, and facing the unexpected with confidence, optimism, and preparedness. My family experience taught me to face a serendipitous world with confidence.

My passion for writing is not about crafting beautiful sentences or verses, but about the simple act of constructing letters and characters with strokes of ink. I find immense satisfaction in this process, which is often spontaneous and subconscious. I'll jot down characters in the margins of notebooks with a humble pencil or trace letters in the air with chopsticks or my fingertips. In an era dominated by keyboards, handwriting is a relic, but one that holds a special significance.

The ancient Chinese believed that "one's handwriting is a painting of one's mind." When I practice my handwriting, I'm not just crafting characters, I'm crafting my character. I take pleasure in meticulously designing each character, stroke by stroke, and building up to a personalized quote that reflects my own voice. Every movement of the pen and every drop of ink leads to something profound, as if the curves of every "m" are doorways to revelations.

Characters are the building blocks of language, and language is the vehicle through which knowledge unfolds. In a way, the letters under my pen are representations of knowledge, and the delicate beauty of each letter proves the intrinsic beauty of knowing. Handwriting reminds me of my conviction that through learning, answers are found, lives are enriched, and societies are bettered.

My passion for handwriting is a testament to my dedication to learning and my zeal for my conviction. It's a crucial aspect of my character. As I write, I'm reminded of David Hilbert's resolute declaration, "We must know..." - a mantra that echoes in my mind as I strive to uncover knowledge.

I'm fascinated by the versatility of handwriting, particularly the various styles developed by the Chinese. Each style - or "hand" - seems to parallel one of my many academic interests. The Regular Hand, with its legible script, serves me well when I'm working through mathematical proofs. The Running Hand, with its semi-cursive script, is like the passionate words I speak before a committee of Model United Nations delegates. And the Cursive Hand, with its spontaneous strokes, is like the artistic sparks that come alive on stage.

The fact that these three distinctive hands can cooperate seamlessly, fusing together the glorious culture of writing, is a testament to the power of learning. It's a reminder that the many talents of the Renaissance Man can come together to enrich human society. My methodology is simple: just as I organize my different hands into a neat personal style, I can unify my broad interests with my passion for learning.

As Hilbert finishes his adage, "...We will know!" I scribble an exclamation mark, the final stroke of this painting of my mind. I must know, for knowing has an inherent beauty and intrinsic value. I will know, for my versatile interests in academics will flow like my versatile styles of writing. I must know, and I will know, for my fetish for writing is a fetish for learning.

When I failed math in my sophomore year of high school, a heated debate erupted in my household. I, the plaintiff, argued that mathematics was too difficult and irrelevant to my goals, citing my recent struggles as evidence. My father, representing the defendant, countered that mathematics was essential for a career in business, which he hoped I would pursue. My brother and sister formed a small jury, and my mother presided over the case as judge.

In a passionate plea, I recounted how I had attempted to learn advanced math concepts, such as the Poisson distribution, but to no avail. I argued that persisting in mathematics would be a futile effort, and I petitioned the court to allow me to focus on the humanities instead. The jury deliberated and ultimately ruled in my favor, declaring that I shouldn't have to take math if I didn't want to. My father was disappointed, but I was thrilled.

However, a year later, new evidence emerged that challenged the initial verdict. Mathematics appealed its sentence, and our makeshift court reconvened. My father reiterated that mathematics was not too difficult or irrelevant, pointing out that I had recently succeeded in pitching a business case to a company, which required mathematical skills. He implored me to give mathematics another chance.

As I reflected on my experience with the business case competition, I realized that mathematical processes made sense when applied in a practical context. I saw how numbers could tell a story and help identify areas of growth. I acknowledged that I had the capacity to succeed in mathematics; I just needed the courage to take on the challenge. With newfound determination, I stood up and announced, "I'll do it." Without waiting for the court's final verdict, I embraced my father, and we began our journey to reconcile with mathematics.

At the age of fourteen, I learned the definition of cancer in my biology class. I confidently answered the question on my chapter 7 test, "The abnormal, unrestricted growth of cells." But it wasn't until two years later that I truly understood the meaning of cancer.

That's when Kiersten, my brother's girlfriend, came into my life. She was a bright light, with her blonde hair and infectious smile, amidst my family's sea of brunettes. She quickly became an integral part of our family, attending my concerts, award ceremonies, and even helping me study for tests. I was grateful for her support, but I had no idea that our roles would soon be reversed.

Kiersten was diagnosed with Stage II Hodgkin's lymphoma at the age of 22. Watching her undergo 20 rounds of chemotherapy was unbearable. Her cancer was later classified as refractory, resistant to treatment, and I felt helpless. I prayed to God, to her cancer, to anyone who would listen, to just leave her alone.

Eventually, Kiersten was able to leave the hospital and stay with my family for six weeks. We transformed our home into a sanctuary, protecting her from outside illnesses. I watched TV with her, baked cookies for her, and marveled at her persistence as she regained strength and achieved remission. In those moments, we beat biology, time, and death, with cookies, TV, and friendship.

But as I looked back on that experience, I realized that I had been so focused on helping Kiersten that I hadn't noticed how she had helped me. I had been afraid to emotionally support someone, unsure of what to say or do. But Kiersten taught me that sometimes, it's not about solving problems intellectually, but about being present, sympathetic, and compassionate.

As I put aside my own worries and troubles to be there for Kiersten, I discovered that my problems seemed to dissipate. The more I talked, laughed, and shared memories with her, the more I realized the power of loyalty, companionship, and optimism in the face of adversity. Kiersten showed me that living to love and loving to live is what truly matters.

Most importantly, she taught me that helping others requires not just intellect and preparation, but solidarity and compassion. And in doing so, I learned to help myself and others with not just my brain, but with my heart. As Robert Frost so eloquently put it, "has made all the difference."

Here is a rewritten version of the passage:

As we laid my grandmother to rest, I couldn't bring myself to throw dirt on her coffin, covered in a mixture of rocks, decomposed matter, and weeds. I felt ashamed for not having said goodbye, for not being able to accept her passing. When my parents finally told me that she had been battling liver cancer, I was 12 and consumed by anger - mostly towards myself. They had wanted to shield me from the harsh reality of death when I was just 6, but their silence had left me feeling guilty and resentful. I had abandoned my sick grandmother for trivial pursuits, and I was determined to make up for it.

I threw myself into my education, believing that knowledge was the key to freeing myself from ignorance. As I learned about cancer in school, I vowed to absorb every detail, to silence the disease that had silenced my grandmother. But my focus soon shifted from learning to achieving academic perfection, thinking that good grades and high test scores would redeem me in her eyes. 

It wasn't until I took a walk on a hiking trail behind my house that I realized the truth. I had lost sight of what truly mattered, and my grandmother's memory had become secondary to my academic ambitions. The natural beauty surrounding me - the blackened trees, colorful pebbles, and wispy clouds - reminded me of my place in the world and my responsibilities to others. 

Volunteering at a cancer treatment center has helped me find my path. When I talk to patients like Ivana, trapped in a moment in time by their diseases, I see my grandmother's kind face in theirs. I remind them that there's more to life than their illness, that they are more than their cancer. As an oncologist, I want to provide emotional support and mental strength to help patients escape the interruption of disease and continue living. Through my work, I can accept the reality of my grandmother's passing without burying her memory.

Every Saturday morning, I'd wake up to the pungent aroma of crushed garlic and spicy pepper. I'd stumble into the kitchen to find my grandma hunched over a large silver bowl, meticulously mixing fresh cabbage leaves with garlic, salt, and red pepper. This was how our beloved Korean dish, kimchi, was born every weekend in our home. My grandma's specialty always took center stage at the dinner table, filling every plate with its bold flavors. The savory smell of garlic seemed like a permanent fixture in our home, just like my grandma's presence.

But even the most treasured recipes are no match for the devastating effects of Alzheimer's disease. Dementia slowly consumed my grandma's memories, leaving her as blank as a new notebook. The ritualistic routine of Saturday mornings came to a halt, and the artificial taste of store-bought kimchi only highlighted the absence of our family tradition. I'd look at her and ask, "Grandma, what's my name?" only to be met with a clueless stare. Within a year of her diagnosis, she lived with us like a stranger.

One day, my mom brought home fresh cabbages and red pepper sauce, reviving the old tradition. As she prepared the ingredients, the familiar tangy smell wafted through the air, and my grandma, drawn by the aroma, slowly got up from the couch and sat beside the silver bowl. Her bony hands, though no longer swift and precise, moved with a determination that belied her frailty. As she shredded the cabbage leaves, her face reflected the aged rigor of a master craftsman. For the first time in years, the smell of garlic filled the air, and the rattling of the silver bowl resonated throughout the house. That night, we savored the imperfect yet precious kimchi, its flavors heightened by the memories it evoked.

I still remember my grandma placing a piece in my mouth and saying, "Here, Dong Jin. Try it, my boy." Seeing her again this summer, that fleeting moment of clarity seemed like a distant memory. Her disheveled hair and expressionless face told of the aggressive progression of her illness. Yet, holding her hands and looking into her eyes, I could still smell that garlic. The memories of Saturday mornings remain etched in my mind. My grandma was an artist who painted the cabbages with bold strokes of red pepper. Like the sweet taste of kimchi, I hope to capture those memories in my writing, preserving what time takes away.

As my grandma used to say, "Tigers leave their fur when they die, humans leave their names." Her legacy is the lingering smell of garlic in our home. Mine will be these words, a testament to the power of memory and the enduring spirit of our family traditions.

As a young child, I contracted the travel bug, and it has been a lifelong affliction. It all began when my grandparents took me to their home in France, sparking a passion that has led me to visit twenty-nine countries and counting. Each destination has provided a unique learning experience, broadening my perspective and shaping my interests.

I vividly remember marveling at the Eiffel Tower in Paris at the age of five, feeding pigeons in Venice's Piazza San Marco at eight, and standing in awe of Stonehenge and the Great Wall of China at thirteen. These experiences not only fueled my wanderlust but also sparked an interest in language. I realized that understanding the local language was key to fully immersing myself in different cultures.

My language journey began with French, which taught me the importance of pronunciation. I recall a humorous encounter in Paris where I mispronounced "Rue des Pyramides" and received a bewildered look from a store owner. This experience emphasized the significance of accurate pronunciation in effective communication.

In eighth grade, I became fascinated with Spanish, discovering the similarities between it and English through cognates. The realization that "baseball" in Spanish is "béisbol," with a similar sound and structure, made speech and comprehension more fluid. Even today, I rely on cognates to help me navigate linguistic challenges.

Later, in high school, I developed a passion for Chinese, mesmerized by the intricate characters and the way they combine to form complex words. I spent hours practicing calligraphy, captivated by the beauty and rhythm of the strokes. Studying foreign languages also led me to explore my native tongue, English, and I began to develop a sesquipedalian lexicon. I became intrigued by etymology, the history of words, and their origins.

My love for language also deepened my appreciation for history, which I came to see as a rich tapestry of stories that have shaped our world. In my freshman year, I took a world history class, and my enthusiasm for the subject grew exponentially.

However, the most significant dimension that language has brought to my life is the ability to form intimate connections with people from diverse backgrounds. When I communicate with individuals in their native language, I find that I can connect with them on a deeper level. I've had the privilege of striking up conversations with people in unexpected places, from a Bulgarian painter in Paris to an Indian woman in Mumbai who used to work at the Argentinian embassy.

My passion for language has led me to pursue a college education in foreign language and linguistics. I am confident that this field will continue to enrich my life, enabling me to connect with people and cultures worldwide. Whether I pursue a career in international business, foreign diplomacy, or translation, I know that my language skills will be an invaluable asset.

As a Chinese proverb taught to me by my teacher goes, "I am like a chicken eating at a mountain of rice." Each grain represents a new word to learn, a new language to master, and a new connection to forge. Today, I still have the travel bug, and I am equally addicted to language, driven by an insatiable thirst for knowledge and connection.

I still remember the moment I faced a moral dilemma that would leave an indelible mark on my life. The prompt may no longer exist, but the experience remains etched in my memory. It was an ordinary day, with me typing away on an English essay, when my cat's loud meows and the flutter of wings disrupted the silence. I turned to find a barely breathing bird lying in front of me. The initial shock was overwhelming - my mind raced, my heart beat faster, and my face drained of blood. But as I instinctively reached out to hold the bird, I was jolted back to reality. This was a living creature, with flesh, blood, and a will to survive.

My reflexes kicked in, and I scrambled to find gloves, napkins, and towels to tend to the bird's wounds. Despite my cat's protests, I carefully picked up the bird, donning yellow rubber gloves to protect myself from its fragile body. As I stroked the bird with a paper towel to clear away the blood, I was met with a gruesome sight - crumpled wings, mangled feet, and a large gash near its jugular. The bird's shallow breathing was a harsh reminder of its mortality.

In that moment, I was transported back to a painful memory - the funeral of my friend Kari Hsieh, who had died in the Chatsworth Metrolink Crash at the age of 17. The grief, the apologies, and the sense of helplessness all came flooding back. But as I held the bird, I felt a surge of determination. I couldn't save Kari, but maybe, just maybe, I could save this bird.

My frantic actions heightened my senses, and I ran outside, hoping the cool air would work a miracle. But as I stood there, cupping the bird in my hands, I realized that it was dying. The line between life and death blurred, and I felt the weight of mortality acutely. Bird, human, human, bird - what was the difference, after all? Both were fragile, both were mortal.

As the bird's warmth faded away, I was left with a sense of despair. I wanted to retreat into my bedroom, confine myself to tears, and replay my memories. But instead, I dug a small hole in the earth and laid the bird to rest. As I covered it with dirt, I felt my own heart grow stronger, my own breath more steady. The wind, the sky, and the damp soil on my hands whispered a gentle truth: "The bird is dead. Kari has passed. But you are alive."

In that moment, I knew that I had to hold on to life, to cherish every breath, every heartbeat, every sweat-drenched moment. As I stood there, surrounded by the silence of nature, I whispered back, "I am alive. I am alive. I am alive."

"As I knelt before the toilet, I vomited up the contents of my stomach. Foaming at the mouth, I felt on the verge of passing out. My body convulsed with uncontrollable shaking, and I gasped for air as the room spun around me. Just ten minutes earlier, I had been enjoying dinner with my family at a Chinese restaurant, savoring a bowl of chicken-feet soup. My mom had specifically asked the waitress if it contained peanuts, aware of my deadly allergy that we discovered when I was two. When the waitress assured us it was peanut-free, I dug in. But soon, I began scratching my neck, feeling the hives that were forming. I rushed to the restroom, desperate to throw up as my throat itched and a weight pressed on my chest. I was experiencing anaphylactic shock, struggling to take anything but shallow breaths. It was as if my own body was fighting against me, the very thing meant to protect and sustain me. At five years old, I couldn't understand what was happening. All I knew was that I felt sick, and I was waiting for my mom to make it better. I thought my parents were superheroes, capable of fixing anything. But when I heard the fear in their voices as they rushed me to the ER, I became scared. After that incident, fear took hold of me. I became afraid of death, eating, and even my own body. As I grew older, I became obsessed with checking food labels and avoided eating if I didn't know what was in the food. I knew the risks of eating something wrong, and I wasn't willing to take that chance. Ultimately, that fear turned into resentment; I resented my body for making me an outsider. But that experience, combined with my regular visits to my allergy specialist, inspired me to pursue a career in allergy research. Even at ten years old, I wanted to find a way to help kids like me. I wanted to find a solution so that nobody would have to endure the same pain, fear, and resentment. As I delved deeper into the medical world, I became fascinated with the body's immune responses, particularly how it reacts to allergens. This past summer, I took a month-long course on human immunology at Stanford University, where I learned about the complex mechanisms and cells that our bodies use to fight off pathogens. My desire to major in biology in college has been fueled by my fascination with the human body, its processes, and my desire to find a way to alleviate the suffering of those with allergies. I hope that one day I can discover a way to stop allergic reactions or at least mitigate their symptoms, so that children and adults don't have to live with the same fear and bitterness that I did."

When I was 16, I lived with the Watkins family in Wichita, Kansas, as part of a foreign exchange student program coordinated by Mrs. Watkins. I babysat her nine-year-old son, Cody, every day after school for two to three hours, playing Scrabble or listening to him read from Charlotte's Web or The Ugly Duckling. He would chat about his friends and school life, and I would ask him about unfamiliar words. Cody became my first friend in the United States.

My second family was the Martinez family, friends of the Watkins. The host dad, Michael, was a high school English teacher, and the host mom, Jennifer (who I called "Jen"), taught elementary school. Although she had just given birth and was still in the hospital when I arrived, the family welcomed me with open arms. We spent quality time together, making pizzas, watching Shrek, and going fishing on Sundays. On rainy days, Michael, Jen, and I would sit on the porch, listening to the rain and discussing our dreams and thoughts. Within two months, I began calling them mom and dad.

After completing the exchange program, I had the option to return to Korea but decided to stay in America to explore new places and meet different people. As I was no longer an exchange student, I had to find a new school and host family on my own. After a thorough search, I found the Struiksma family in California. They were a unique family, with Shellie, the single mom, having two biological sons and two adopted Russian daughters. The kids were always well-behaved and had a warm meal ready. Shellie's upbringing was the key to their discipline. My room was on the first floor, next to her hair salon, and the living room was equipped with massive amplifiers and a grand chandelier. Although the constant stream of visitors made me nervous at first, I soon grew accustomed to it. However, after a few months, I realized we weren't the best fit, and I politely told them I had to leave. They understood my decision.

My fourth family was the Ortiz family. Kimberly, the host mom, treated me like one of her own, assigning me chores like cooking dinner, feeding their dogs, and cleaning the bathroom. I also had to follow certain rules, such as no food in my room, no using the family computer, and no lights after midnight. The first few months were tough, but I eventually adjusted. I lived with the Ortiz family for seven months, but when Greg's asthma worsened, they decided to move to the countryside. I had to find a new host family within a week, and my friend Danielle offered me a temporary place to stay until I found a new home. That's how I met the Dirksen family, my fifth and final family.

The Dirksen family had three kids, each with their own unique preferences. We would play Wii Sports together after dinner, and I was the bowling champion. Afterward, we would gather in the living room, where Danielle would play the piano, and we would sing hymns together. I don't remember a single argument about the games.

Although my 28 months with these five families were too short to fully understand each of them, I learned valuable lessons from each. Cody taught me the importance of learning from anyone; the Martinez family showed me the value of quality family time; the Struiksma family taught me not to judge divorced women and adopted children; Mrs. Ortiz taught me the importance of discipline; and the Dirksen family taught me to appreciate individual differences. Living with five families has made me more sensitive to others' needs, and I've learned to recognize when someone needs to talk, when to offer advice, and when to simply listen. I've become more adaptable and am ready to change, learn, and be shaped by my future families.

For most of my life, I was addicted to processed snack foods and animal products, dominating my kitchen and diet. However, everything changed when my mom was diagnosed with cancer and switched to a 100% whole food plant-based diet. I decided to support her by adopting this new way of eating, and together we dove into the world of nutritional science. We binge-watched documentaries like "What the Health" and "Forks Over Knives," and read books by featured doctors like "The China Study" and "How Not To Die." I became fascinated by the impact of diet on health and discovered how certain foods could prevent cancer, boost metabolism, and even cure acne and heart disease. I learned to pair foods to achieve the perfect macronutrient balance and was amazed by the benefits of plant-based eating, such as how beans and rice make a complete protein. This new lifestyle also sparked a passion for sustainability in me, as I realized that animal agriculture has a devastating impact on the planet. I began making small changes, like switching to reusable beeswax wraps and a foldable straw, to reduce my ecological footprint. My journey led me to become co-leader of the Northern Nevada PlantPure Pod, where we're working to encourage local restaurants to offer plant-based, oil-free menu options. I even dream of opening my own affordable oatmeal cafe, where I can educate people about nutritional science through delicious, healthy food. I believe that hands-on experience is the best way to learn about the benefits of a plant-based lifestyle, so I love cooking and experimenting with new flavors. By using my taste buds as my textbook, I can teach others about the benefits of whole, plant-based foods and show them that healthy food doesn't have to be boring. As a result of my new lifestyle, I have more energy and have been able to push myself harder physically, even earning my high school Cross Country team's Most Improved award. While I'm still a picky eater, my preferences have changed, and I'm proud to call myself a vegeholic.

For the past 700 days, I've been maintaining a digital journal called the Happiness Spreadsheet, where I record my daily happiness level on a scale of 1 to 20, accompanied by a brief description of my day. The spreadsheet has become more than just a numerical record; it's a collection of memories and experiences that have shaped my life. A "14" on November 15, 2018, marked the inaugural meeting of the Lakeside Cooking on the Stove Club, which started as a whimsical idea but evolved into a biweekly gathering where friends and I prepare savory snacks. A "16" on February 27, 2019, commemorated the completion of a fence we built for a small Colombian village, a project that brought us closer to the community we grew to love. The Happiness Spreadsheet isn't just a reflection of my emotions; it's a testament to the joy I derive from bringing happiness to others. My family is the foundation of my life, with each member representing a unique neighborhood, each with their own story. When I'm overwhelmed, I turn to my father, who teaches me to look beyond the chaos and appreciate the hidden accomplishments. My mother, with her tranquil and sturdy background, helps me build confidence when I need it most. Whenever my happiness levels dip, my family is always there to support me. The Happiness Spreadsheet also serves as a gauge for my enthusiasm, which can be fully charged, like when I won a piano composition competition, or depleted, like when I'm struggling with writer's block. The spreadsheet can be a hall of fame, but it can also be a catalog of mistakes and challenges. It all began on a typical school day, after a confusing physics test, when I spontaneously came up with the idea and shared it with two friends. We thought it would last only a few weeks, but 700 days later, we're still going strong. With each new entry, I realize that it's not the individual data points that define me, but the ever-growing line that connects them, reflecting who I am today.
