The title "Mission Possible!" still screamed at me, but now it was a reminder of what I was capable of. I knew that no matter what challenges lay ahead, I was ready. I was up for it.

M7652-000. Or at least that's how my bike-tire-greased, highlight-yellow, heel-cap-ripping-at-the-seams Chuck-Taylors are supposed to be colored. Freshman year, I tried so hard to keep them that pristine, popular M7652-000 color. Time progressed, however, and dirt, guitar chords, and conversations eventually covered the canvas of the shoes. When I first moved to Houston in eighth grade, I tried to follow the status quo and keep my shoes white. But as various conflicting influences crept into my life--Liberal vs. Conservative; Portland, OR vs. Houston, TX; LCD Sound system vs. Ed Sheeran--I began to realize how important it is to listen to the other side and to maintain the confidence to pursue my passions while inspiring others to do the same. I needed to appreciate Houston's voice and learn from its stories as much as it needed to hear mine, and my shoes grew dirtier every day as each person's testimony helped solidify and expand my own. As I walked through the bustling streets of Houston, my shoes became a reflection of my journey. The dirt and stains accumulated, telling the story of late-night conversations with friends, impromptu jam sessions, and spontaneous adventures. Each scuff mark and smudge represented a moment of growth, a lesson learned, or a connection made. My shoes became a testament to the beauty of imperfection, a reminder that true character is forged in the fires of experience, not in the sterile vacuum of conformity.

As I navigated the complexities of high school, I began to realize that the same principles applied to my relationships and interactions with others. I learned to appreciate the diverse perspectives and backgrounds that surrounded me, to listen actively, and to empathize deeply. I discovered that the most profound connections were formed when I was willing to get my hands dirty, to engage in messy, uncomfortable conversations, and to challenge my own assumptions.

My shoes, once a symbol of superficiality, had transformed into a badge of honor, a symbol of my commitment to authenticity and self-expression. I no longer felt the need to conform to the expectations of others, to present a polished, Instagram-perfect facade. Instead, I embraced the beauty of my imperfections, the quirks and flaws that made me uniquely me.

As I looked down at my worn, faded Chucks, I was reminded of the power of storytelling. Each stain, each scuff, each tear told a story of its own, a story of resilience, of perseverance, of growth. My shoes had become a canvas, a tapestry woven from the threads of my experiences, and I was proud to wear them as a badge of honor.

In a world that often values superficiality over substance, my shoes stood as a defiant rebuke. They proclaimed that true beauty lies not in the pristine, the polished, or the perfect, but in the worn, the weathered, and the well-loved. They whispered that it's okay to be imperfect, to be messy, to be human.

As I walked through the streets of Houston, my shoes making soft crunching sounds on the pavement, I felt a sense of pride, of ownership, of self. I knew that I was not just a product of my environment, but a co-creator, a storyteller, a work of art in progress. And my shoes, those trusty, tattered Chucks, were the perfect reflection of that journey.

On one hot night in a dark room at the heart of Boston, I became friends with 19,580 people in one single moment. We had all journeyed to the TD Garden from wherever we were in our lives to see Tom Petty perform. I knew his music because my mother had shared it with me. It meant something to her and it meant something to me. His music meant something different to every person in that room and all those meanings, all infinite number of them, wrapped around the music notes and existed in harmony on that July night. I had to close my eyes. It was as if I could hear the heartbeats of every person in that room, pulsing along with the rhythm of the music. By sharing his music, Tom Petty gave me a striking awareness of 19,580 people that live and feel alongside each other. Tom Petty will live as long as people feel. Lights flashing beyond my eyelids, I could feel what it was like to live more lives than just my own. Tom Petty's art described his life, but it has weaved its way into those of so many others. My own, my mother's then and when she was my age, and all the strangers around me who didn't seem so strange anymore. We all have to go through our own lives and our own challenges, but just because we have our own lessons to learn doesn't mean we are alone. As I stood there, surrounded by the pulsating energy of the crowd, I felt a deep sense of connection to the people around me. It was as if Tom Petty's music had bridged the gaps between our individual experiences, creating a collective understanding that transcended our differences. In that moment, I realized that his art was not just a reflection of his own life, but a thread that stitched together the tapestry of human experience.

As I looked around the room, I saw people of all ages, backgrounds, and walks of life, united by their love for Tom Petty's music. I saw tears streaming down the faces of those who had lost loved ones, and I saw smiles on the faces of those who had found solace in his songs. I saw people singing along to every word, their voices hoarse from years of belting out their favorite tunes. And I saw people like me, who had been introduced to his music by a loved one, and had found a piece of themselves in his lyrics.

Tom Petty's music was more than just a collection of songs – it was a shared experience, a common language that spoke to our deepest fears, desires, and hopes. It was a reminder that we are not alone in our struggles, that we are all connected by our shared humanity. As I stood there, surrounded by the pulsating energy of the crowd, I felt a sense of gratitude to Tom Petty for giving me this gift – the gift of connection, of community, of understanding.

As the night wore on, and the music faded into the silence, I knew that I would carry this feeling with me long after the concert was over. I would carry it with me as I navigated the ups and downs of life, as I faced my own challenges and struggles. And I would carry it with me as I connected with others, as I formed new relationships and deepened old ones.

Tom Petty may have left us, but his music remains, a testament to the power of art to bring us together, to make us feel seen and heard and understood. And as I looked around the room, I knew that I was not alone in this feeling – that there were 19,580 people who felt the same way, who had been touched by his music in a way that would stay with them forever.

My first dream job was to be a pickle truck driver. I saw it in my favorite book, Richard Scarry's "Cars and Trucks and Things That Go," and for some reason, I was absolutely obsessed with the idea of driving a giant pickle. Much to the discontent of my younger sister, I insisted that my parents read us that book as many nights as possible so we could find goldbug, a small little golden bug, on every page. I would imagine the wonderful life I would have: being a pig driving a giant pickle truck across the country, chasing and finding goldbug. I then moved on to wanting to be a Lego Master. As I grew older, my dream jobs continued to evolve, but the sense of adventure and creativity remained a constant theme. I wanted to be a Lego Master because I was fascinated by the endless possibilities of building and creating something from scratch. I would spend hours constructing intricate cities, spaceships, and castles, and I loved the feeling of bringing my imagination to life. My parents, seeing my passion, encouraged me to pursue it, and I began to participate in local Lego competitions, where I would meet other kids who shared my enthusiasm.

As I entered middle school, my interests shifted again, and I became obsessed with the idea of being a marine biologist. I was captivated by the wonders of the ocean and the creatures that lived within it. I would spend hours watching documentaries about sharks, coral reefs, and sea turtles, and I dreamed of one day exploring the depths of the ocean in a submarine. I even started a small aquarium in my room, where I would care for fish and learn about the delicate balance of marine ecosystems.

In high school, I discovered my passion for writing and storytelling. I began to write short stories and poetry, and I fell in love with the power of words to evoke emotions and transport people to new worlds. I started a school literary magazine, where I would publish the work of my fellow students, and I even landed an internship at a local publishing house. I thought that I had finally found my dream job – to be a published author, traveling the world and telling stories that would inspire and captivate people.

But as I entered college, I began to realize that my dream job was not just about the job itself, but about the impact it would have on others. I started to volunteer at a local literacy program, where I would teach underprivileged kids how to read and write. It was there that I saw the power of education to transform lives, and I knew that I wanted to be a part of it. I changed my major to education, and I began to pursue a career as a teacher.

Looking back, I realize that my dream jobs were not just fleeting fancies, but a reflection of my values and passions. Being a pickle truck driver, a Lego Master, a marine biologist, a writer, and a teacher may seem like vastly different careers, but they all share a common thread – a desire to explore, create, and make a difference in the world. As I continue on my journey, I know that my dream job will continue to evolve, but I am excited to see where it will take me next.

On Tuesdays and Thursdays, I sit in soil pulling crab grass and borage. I've been a farmer since sophomore year. The farm--managed by my school--is a one-acre plot more accurately described as a garden with chickens. My task today is to pick cherry tomatoes, most of which have ripened. I grab a tray from the shed and walk across pathways to the vine. I created these pathways during junior year, shoveling large heaps of wood-chips into a wheelbarrow, then raking these chips onto the pathways between beds. Our two tomato vines stand three feet tall and extend horizontally at least six feet; they are heavy with small red and orange glistening spheres. As I begin to pick the cherry tomatoes, the warm sun beats down on my back, and the sweet aroma of ripe fruit fills the air. I gently twist each tomato from its stem, careful not to bruise the delicate skin. The tray quickly fills with the vibrant red and orange orbs, and I take a moment to admire my handiwork. There's something satisfying about watching something you've nurtured grow and flourish.

As I work, I think back to how I first got involved with the farm. It was during my sophomore year, when I was struggling to find my place in school. I was always interested in science and the outdoors, but I didn't know how to channel that interest into something meaningful. That was when I stumbled upon the farm club, a small group of students who were passionate about sustainable agriculture. I was drawn to their enthusiasm and dedication, and soon found myself volunteering on the farm every week.

Over time, I took on more responsibilities, learning about crop rotation, composting, and irrigation systems. I discovered that farming wasn't just about growing food; it was about building a community, working together towards a common goal. The farm became my sanctuary, a place where I could escape the pressures of school and focus on something tangible.

As I continue to pick tomatoes, I notice the chickens pecking at the ground nearby, searching for bugs and seeds. We have five chickens in total, each with its own unique personality. There's Luna, the curious one, who always seems to find her way into trouble. Then there's Ginger, the gentle giant, who loves to be petted and cuddled. The chickens are an integral part of the farm, providing us with fresh eggs and entertainment.

After I've filled the tray with tomatoes, I take a break to sit under the shade of a nearby tree. I pull out a water bottle and take a refreshing sip, feeling the cool liquid slide down my throat. As I sit there, I reflect on what I've learned from my experience as a farmer. It's not just about growing food; it's about cultivating patience, perseverance, and a deeper connection with the natural world.

As I look out at the garden, I feel a sense of pride and accomplishment. We've worked hard to create this oasis, and it's a testament to what can be achieved when people come together with a shared vision. The farm has taught me that even in the midst of chaos, there is always beauty to be found. And as I head back to the shed, tray in hand, I know that I'll carry this lesson with me for the rest of my life.

The rest of the afternoon passes quickly, as I help with other tasks around the farm. We have a meeting to discuss our plans for the upcoming harvest festival, and I volunteer to help with the setup. As the sun begins to set, I pack up my things and head back to school, feeling fulfilled and content. Being a farmer has taught me to appreciate the simple things in life, and I know that no matter where life takes me, I'll always cherish this experience.

My math teacher turns around to write an equation on the board and a sun pokes out from the collar of her shirt. A Starbucks barista hands me my drink with a hand adorned by a small music note. Where I work, a customer hands me her credit card wearing a permanent flower bracelet. Every day, I am on a scavenger hunt to find women with this kind of permanent art. I'm intrigued by the quotes, dates, symbols, and abstract shapes I see on people that I interact with daily. As I go about my daily routine, I find myself scanning the arms, legs, and torsos of the people I encounter, searching for these hidden gems. It's become a game, a thrill of the hunt, to spot a new tattoo and wonder about the story behind it. What inspired this person to choose this particular design? What does it represent to them?

I've come to realize that tattoos are more than just decorative body art; they're a form of self-expression, a way for individuals to convey their personality, values, and experiences. Each tattoo is a unique window into the wearer's soul, a glimpse into their history and what makes them tick.

I've had the privilege of striking up conversations with some of these tattooed individuals, and their stories are always fascinating. There was the young woman with a delicate cherry blossom on her ankle, which symbolized her grandmother's love and the beauty of impermanence. Then there was the burly man with a sleeve of skulls and snakes, which represented his journey through addiction and redemption.

These encounters have not only broadened my understanding of tattoos but also changed my perception of the people who wear them. I used to think of tattoos as a form of rebellion or nonconformity, but now I see them as a badge of courage, a sign of vulnerability, and a testament to the human experience.

As I continue on my scavenger hunt, I've started to notice patterns and themes. There are the music lovers, with their treble clefs and guitar strings, who wear their passion on their sleeves. There are the travelers, with their maps and compasses, who have etched their journeys onto their skin. And then there are the survivors, with their ribbons and awareness symbols, who have transformed their struggles into symbols of hope and resilience.

These tattoos are more than just ink on skin; they're a language, a way for people to communicate their essence without words. They're a reminder that everyone has a story to tell, and that each person we meet is a complex tapestry of experiences, emotions, and values.

As I go about my day, I'm no longer just seeing people; I'm seeing the art that adorns their bodies, and the stories that lie beneath. I'm seeing the beauty in the imperfections, the courage in the vulnerabilities, and the humanity in the ink. My scavenger hunt has become a journey of discovery, not just of tattoos, but of the people who wear them, and the incredible stories they have to tell.

“Biogeochemical. It's a word, I promise!” There are shrieks and shouts in protest and support. Unacceptable insults are thrown, degrees and qualifications are questioned, I think even a piece of my grandmother's famously flakey parantha whizzes past my ear. Everyone is too lazy to take out a dictionary (or even their phones) to look it up, so we just hash it out. And then, I am crowned the victor, a true success in the Merchant household. As I bask in the glory of my triumph, my family's raucous debate slowly dies down, and we all collapse into laughter. It's moments like these that I cherish, when our competitive spirits and love for words come together in a beautiful mess. My grandmother, still chuckling, pats me on the back and says, "Beta, you've always had a way with words." My parents, still grinning, exchange a proud glance.

As we settle down, my mom suggests we take a break from our usual Sunday afternoon routine of watching TV or taking a nap. "Why don't we play a game?" she asks, her eyes sparkling with mischief. My siblings and I exchange excited glances, knowing that our mom's game nights are always legendary. We quickly agree, and my mom pulls out an old favorite: Scattergories.

The game is a perfect fit for our word-loving family. We spend the next few hours laughing, arguing, and creating outrageous categories. My siblings and I team up against our parents, determined to finally beat them. The competition is fierce, but in the end, we emerge victorious, much to our parents' dismay.

As the evening draws to a close, we all gather around the dinner table, exhausted but exhilarated. My grandmother serves her famous parantha, and we dig in, savoring the crispy, flaky goodness. The conversation turns to our favorite books and authors, and we spend the rest of the evening discussing everything from Austen to Zadie Smith.

In this chaotic, loving household, words are our currency, our passion, and our connection. We may not always agree on the definition of "biogeochemical," but we agree on the importance of language, laughter, and love. As I look around the table, I know that this is where I belong – surrounded by the people and words that make me whole.

“You’re such a hipster.” It’s a phrase heard everyday in school hallways across America, and its usage often operates as a conundrum that obscures teenagers’ perceptions of themselves and who they want to be. I, in turn, have struggled immensely with the paradoxical use of this label. Since the onset of my tween years and perhaps even before that, I have constantly carried with me an insistent urge for nonconformity; it has never sat well with me to be like everyone else. Throughout my middle school years, this natural instinct of mine manifested itself in many different ways: jeans tucked into knee-high socks, anything from punk to Harlem renaissance jazz bellowing from my headphones, Palahniuk novels peeking out of my backpack. As my identity shifted, my career as a social renegade flourished, and I found in myself a certain pride in being different and a passion for seeking out eccentric new ways to express myself. However, as I entered high school, the label "hipster" began to take on a new meaning. It was no longer a badge of honor, but a term of ridicule and scorn. Suddenly, my eclectic style and love for underground music were seen as pretentious and superficial. I was accused of trying too hard to be different, of being a poser who only adopted alternative interests to seem cool. The phrase "you're such a hipster" was hurled at me like a insult, implying that I was somehow inauthentic, that my nonconformity was just a shallow attempt to stand out.

At first, I was taken aback by this sudden shift in perception. I had always thought that being different was something to be proud of, but now it seemed like a liability. I began to question whether my passion for individuality was genuine or just a facade. Was I really just trying to fit into a certain mold, to be accepted by a certain crowd? The uncertainty was crippling, and for a while, I felt like I was losing myself in the midst of it all.

But as I reflected on my experiences, I realized that the problem wasn't with me or my desire for nonconformity. The issue lay with the way the term "hipster" was being used - as a way to dismiss and belittle anyone who dared to be different. It was a label that reduced complex individuals to a set of superficial characteristics, ignoring the depth and sincerity behind their actions. I realized that my passion for alternative music, literature, and fashion wasn't about trying to fit into a certain crowd, but about expressing myself authentically.

Moreover, I came to understand that the desire for nonconformity wasn't unique to me or even to the "hipster" subculture. It was a fundamental human impulse, a need to break free from the constraints of societal norms and forge one's own path. In embracing this impulse, I was not only staying true to myself, but also contributing to a rich cultural heritage of innovation and creativity.

In the end, the label "hipster" lost its power over me. I continued to wear my skinny jeans and listen to my vinyl records, not because I was trying to fit into a certain mold, but because it was a genuine expression of who I was. And as I looked around at my peers, I saw that we were all struggling with the same paradox - the desire to be different, yet the fear of being labeled and judged. But it was in embracing this paradox, in owning our individuality and rejecting the superficial labels, that we could truly find ourselves and forge our own paths in life.

I had never broken into a car before. We were in Laredo, having just finished our first day at a Habitat for Humanity work site. The Hotchkiss volunteers had already left, off to enjoy some Texas BBQ, leaving me behind with the college kids to clean up. Not until we were stranded did we realize we were locked out of the van. Someone picked a coat hanger out of the dumpster, handed it to me, and took a few steps back. "Can you do that thing with a coat hanger to unlock it?" "Why me?" I thought to myself, but before I could respond, one of the college kids chimed in, "Yeah, you're from the city, you must know how to do that stuff." I was taken aback by the assumption, but I decided to roll with it. After all, I had seen it done in movies before, how hard could it be?

I took the coat hanger and began to manipulate it, trying to recreate the scenes I had seen on screen. The college kids gathered around, watching with a mix of curiosity and amusement. I poked and prodded at the lock, trying to get it to budge, but it wouldn't give. Sweat began to form on my forehead as I worked, my hands shaking slightly with the effort.

Just when I was about to give up, I felt a slight click. The lock disengaged, and the door swung open. The college kids cheered, and I couldn't help but feel a sense of pride and accomplishment. Who knew that my fake reputation as a city kid with a talent for breaking and entering would actually come in handy?

As we piled back into the van, I couldn't help but think about the irony of the situation. Here we were, a group of volunteers dedicated to building affordable housing for those in need, and yet we were resorting to questionable tactics to get back into our own vehicle. It was a humbling reminder that even with the best of intentions, we're not above making mistakes.

The rest of the trip was a blur of long days and hard work, but that moment stuck with me. It was a reminder that even in the most unexpected situations, we have the power to surprise ourselves. And it was a testament to the power of teamwork and quick thinking, even when things don't go according to plan.

As we drove away from Laredo, headed back to our respective homes, I couldn't help but think about the lessons I had learned on that trip. It wasn't just about building houses; it was about building relationships, and learning to adapt to unexpected situations. And it was about discovering hidden talents and skills that we never knew we had.

That trip was a turning point for me, a moment of self-discovery that has stayed with me to this day. It reminded me that even in the most mundane of situations, there is always the potential for adventure and growth. And it taught me that sometimes, it's the unexpected moments that end up being the most memorable.

Years later, when I look back on that trip, I'm reminded of the power of community and the importance of taking risks. I'm reminded that even when things don't go according to plan, we have the power to adapt and overcome. And I'm reminded that sometimes, it's the unexpected moments that end up being the most transformative.

That trip to Laredo was just a small part of my journey, but it's a memory that I'll carry with me for the rest of my life. It's a reminder that even in the most unexpected situations, we have the power to surprise ourselves, and to discover new strengths and abilities that we never knew we had.

I have a fetish for writing. I’m not talking about crafting prose or verses, or even sentences out of words. But simply constructing letters and characters from strokes of ink gives me immense satisfaction. It’s not quite calligraphy, as I don’t use calligraphic pens or Chinese writing brushes; I prefer it simple, spontaneous, and subconscious. I often find myself crafting characters in the margins of notebooks with a fifty-cent pencil, or tracing letters out of thin air with anything from chopsticks to fingertips. The art of handwriting is a relic in the information era. Why write when one can type? Yet, for me, the tactile experience of putting pen to paper, or rather, pencil to paper, is an essential part of the creative process. It's a sensory experience that typing on a keyboard cannot replicate. The feel of the graphite gliding across the page, the subtle variations in pressure and speed that can alter the shape and size of the letters, the way the lead wears down to a nub, leaving a trail of graphite dust in its wake – all of these sensations are integral to the joy I derive from writing.

Moreover, handwriting is an intimate, personal act. It's a reflection of one's personality, a window into the subconscious. The loops and flourishes, the tightness or looseness of the script, the way certain letters are favored over others – all of these reveal something about the writer's character. In an era where digital communication has become the norm, handwriting is a rare and precious commodity. It's a tangible connection to the past, a link to the countless generations who have put pen to paper to express themselves.

I often find myself lost in the flow of handwriting, the strokes and curves of the letters blending together in a hypnotic dance. It's a meditative state, one that quiets the mind and focuses the attention. The world outside recedes, and all that's left is the gentle scratch of the pencil on paper, the soft whisper of the graphite as it leaves its mark.

Of course, there are practical advantages to handwriting as well. Studies have shown that writing by hand improves retention and recall, that it enhances cognitive function and boosts creativity. In an age where information is readily available at our fingertips, handwriting forces us to slow down, to process and absorb the information in a more meaningful way.

But for me, the appeal of handwriting goes beyond the practical or cognitive benefits. It's an act of rebellion, a refusal to surrender to the homogenizing forces of technology. In a world where everything is instant, where communication is reduced to emojis and abbreviations, handwriting is a defiant assertion of individuality.

As I sit here, pencil in hand, crafting letters and characters in the margins of my notebook, I feel a sense of connection to the writers who have come before me. I think of the great authors, the poets and novelists who poured their hearts and souls onto the page, leaving behind a legacy of ink and paper. I think of the countless love letters, the diaries and journals, the scribbled notes and marginalia that have been lost to the ages.

And I think of the future, of the generations to come who will inherit our digital detritus, our tweets and texts and emails. Will they cherish these ephemeral messages, or will they be lost in the void, forgotten in the vast expanse of cyberspace? I don't know, but I do know that the handwritten word, with all its imperfections and quirks, will endure. It's a testament to the human touch, a reminder that even in the most sterile of digital landscapes, there is still beauty to be found in the strokes of a pencil, the flow of ink on paper.

When I failed math in my sophomore year of high school, a bitter dispute engulfed my household -- “Nicolas Yan vs. Mathematics.” I was the plaintiff, appearing pro se, while my father represented the defendant (inanimate as it was). My brother and sister constituted a rather understaffed jury, and my mother presided over the case as judge. In a frightening departure from racial stereotype, I charged Mathematics with the capital offences of being “too difficult” and “irrelevant to my aspirations,” citing my recent shortcomings in the subject as evi. as evidence of its alleged wrongdoing. My father, a stalwart defender of the mathematical arts, countered with a scathing cross-examination, probing the depths of my study habits and questioning my commitment to the subject. The jury, comprised of my siblings, seemed sympathetic to my plight, but ultimately, they were swayed by my father's impassioned argument that mathematics was not only essential to my academic success but also a vital tool for problem-solving in everyday life.

As the verdict was read – guilty of not applying myself – I felt a mix of emotions: disappointment, frustration, and a hint of defiance. How could my family not understand that math just wasn't my thing? I had always struggled with numbers, and no amount of tutoring or extra help seemed to make a difference. But as I reflected on the trial, I began to realize that my failure in math wasn't just about the subject itself; it was about my own fear of failure and my reluctance to ask for help.

In the months that followed, I made a conscious effort to change my approach to math. I started attending tutoring sessions regularly, not just to improve my grades but to understand the underlying concepts. I also began to see math in a different light, recognizing its beauty and elegance in the way it described the world around us. My grades slowly began to improve, and with them, my confidence.

The experience taught me a valuable lesson about perseverance and the importance of seeking help when needed. It also made me appreciate the value of constructive criticism, even when it comes from those closest to us. My father's tough love and high expectations pushed me to work harder and strive for excellence, even in a subject that didn't come naturally to me.

As I look back on that tumultuous period in my life, I am reminded of the power of family and the impact they can have on our lives. The "trial" may have been a dramatic and humorous way to address my struggles in math, but it was also a testament to the unwavering support and guidance that my family has always provided. In the end, it was not mathematics that was the problem; it was my own attitude and approach to learning.

The experience has also influenced my approach to challenges in general. When faced with obstacles, I no longer shy away or become discouraged. Instead, I draw on the lessons I learned from my "trial" and remind myself that with persistence, hard work, and a willingness to ask for help, I can overcome even the most daunting hurdles.

In many ways, the "Nicolas Yan vs. Mathematics" trial was a defining moment in my life, one that taught me valuable lessons about resilience, hard work, and the importance of family. It may have started as a humorous and lighthearted dispute, but it ultimately became a transformative experience that has shaped me into the person I am today.

I learned the definition of cancer at the age of fourteen. I was taking my chapter 7 biology test when I came upon the last question, “What is cancer?”, to which I answered: “The abnormal, unrestricted growth of cells.” After handing in the test, I moved on to chapter 8, oblivious then to how earth-shattering such a disease could be. I learned the meaning of cancer two years later. A girl named Kiersten came into my family by way of my oldest brother who had fallen in love with her. I distinctly recall her hair catching the sea breeze as she walked with us along the Jersey shore, a blonde wave in my surrounding family's sea of brunette. Physically, she may have been different, but she redefined what family meant to me. She attended my concerts, went to my award ceremonies, and helped me study for tests. Whenever I needed support, she was there. But little did I know, Kiersten was hiding a secret. One day, my brother sat me down and told me that Kiersten had been diagnosed with cancer. I was in shock, my mind racing back to that biology test two years prior. The definition I had so confidently written down seemed so trivial now. I couldn't fathom how something so seemingly abstract could be wreaking havoc on the person I had grown to love.

As Kiersten began her treatment, I watched her transformation from a vibrant, energetic young woman to a frail, exhausted patient. Her once-luxuriant hair fell out in clumps, her skin turned pale, and her bright smile began to fade. I felt helpless, unable to do anything but stand by and watch as cancer ravaged her body. The pain and suffering she endured was a harsh reality check, and I was forced to confront the brutal truth about this disease.

Despite the grueling treatment, Kiersten's spirit remained unbroken. She continued to attend my concerts, albeit in a wheelchair, and still managed to muster a smile whenever I needed it. Her resilience in the face of adversity inspired me, and I began to realize that cancer was not just a disease, but a test of human strength and courage.

As the months went by, Kiersten's battle with cancer became a defining aspect of our family's life. We rallied around her, supporting her through the darkest of times. I learned to appreciate the little things, like a good day, a decent night's sleep, or a moment of laughter amidst the tears. I saw firsthand the importance of family, friends, and community in the fight against cancer.

Kiersten's journey with cancer taught me that life is precious, fragile, and unpredictable. It showed me that even in the darkest moments, there is always hope, always a reason to keep fighting. And although cancer may have taken its toll on her body, it could never diminish her spirit, her love, or her impact on my life. Today, as I reflect on that biology test and the lessons I've learned since, I realize that the true meaning of cancer goes far beyond a simple definition – it's a testament to the human spirit's capacity to persevere, to love, and to inspire.

They covered the precious mahogany coffin with a brown amalgam of rocks, decomposed organisms, and weeds. It was my turn to take the shovel, but I felt too ashamed to dutifully send her off when I had not properly said goodbye. I refused to throw dirt on her. I refused to let go of my grandmother, to accept a death I had not seen coming, to believe that an illness could not only interrupt, but steal a beloved life. When my parents finally revealed to me that my grandmother had been battling liver cancer, I was twelve and I was angry--mostly with myself. They had wanted to protect me--only six years old at the time--from the complex and morose concept of death. As I stood there, frozen in grief, my parents' words echoed in my mind. They had wanted to shield me from the harsh reality of mortality, but in doing so, they had also deprived me of the opportunity to say goodbye, to come to terms with her illness, and to prepare myself for the inevitable. I felt cheated, as if I had been robbed of precious time with my grandmother.

In the days that followed, I struggled to reconcile my emotions. I was angry with my parents for not telling me sooner, but at the same time, I understood their motivations. They had wanted to preserve my childhood innocence, to let me enjoy the carefree days of youth without the burden of mortality weighing me down. But as I navigated the complex web of emotions that followed my grandmother's passing, I realized that their decision had also stolen from me the chance to develop a deeper understanding of life and death.

As I looked around at my family, gathered together in mourning, I saw the weight of grief etched on their faces. My parents, who had always been my pillars of strength, seemed fragile and vulnerable. My siblings, who had always been my partners in mischief, were somber and quiet. We were all struggling to come to terms with the loss, to find a way to move forward in a world without our beloved grandmother.

In the weeks and months that followed, I began to realize that my grandmother's death was not just a personal loss, but also a rite of passage. It marked the end of my childhood innocence and the beginning of my journey towards adulthood. I began to understand that life was precious, fleeting, and unpredictable. I learned to cherish every moment, to appreciate the beauty of the present, and to find meaning in the impermanence of life.

As I reflect on that difficult time, I am grateful for the lessons I learned. I am grateful for the opportunity to understand the complexity of human emotions, to develop empathy and compassion, and to appreciate the beauty of life. My grandmother's death was a painful experience, but it was also a transformative one. It taught me to live life with intention, to cherish every moment, and to find meaning in the impermanence of life.

In the end, I did take the shovel, and I did throw dirt on her grave. But it was not an act of closure; it was an act of acceptance. I accepted that my grandmother was gone, but I also accepted that her memory would live on in me. I accepted that life was precious, and that every moment counted. And I accepted that I would carry her legacy with me, always.

Every Saturday morning, I’d awaken to the smell of crushed garlic and piquant pepper. I would stumble into the kitchen to find my grandma squatting over a large silver bowl, mixing fat lips of fresh cabbages with garlic, salt, and red pepper. That was how the delectable Korean dish, kimchi, was born every weekend at my home. My grandma’s specialty always dominated the dinner table as kimchi filled every plate. And like my grandma who had always been living with us, it seemed as though the luscious smell of garlic would never leave our home. But even the prided recipe was defenseless against the ravages of Alzheimer’s that inflicted my grandma’s mind. Dementia slowly fed on her memories until she became as blank as a brand-new notebook. The ritualistic rigor of Saturday mornings came to a pause, and during dinner, the artificial taste of vacuum-packaged factory kimchi only emphasized the absence of the family tradition. I would look at her and ask, “Grandma, what’s my name?” But she would stare back at me with a clueless expression. Within a year of diagnosis, she lived with us like a total stranger. One day, my mom brought home fresh cabbages and red pepper sauce. and placed them on the kitchen counter, hoping to spark some memory in my grandma's mind. She sat beside her, holding her hands, and said, "Mom, remember how we used to make kimchi together every Saturday?" My grandma's eyes wandered, unfocused, as if searching for a familiar face in a crowded room. My mom's voice trembled, but she persisted, "Let's make kimchi together, just like we used to." Slowly, my grandma's gaze settled on the cabbages, and for a fleeting moment, a glimmer of recognition flickered in her eyes.

With my mom's guidance, my grandma's hands began to move, as if on autopilot, mimicking the motions she had performed countless times before. The familiar rhythm of chopping, mixing, and seasoning returned, and the aroma of garlic and pepper wafted through the air once more. It was as if the kimchi had awakened a part of her that Alzheimer's had tried to erase. For that brief, shining moment, my grandma was back, her eyes sparkling with a hint of her former self.

As we sat down to eat the kimchi, the flavors exploded on my tongue, transporting me back to those Saturday mornings when life was simpler. My grandma took a bite, and a faint smile crossed her face. It was a small victory, but it was enough to give us hope. In that instant, I realized that even as memories fade, the love and traditions that bind us together can still be savored, and that the smell of garlic and pepper can evoke a sense of home and belonging, even in the darkest of times.

When I was very little, I caught the travel bug. It started after my grandparents first brought me to their home in France and I have now been to twenty-nine different countries. Each has given me a unique learning experience. At five, I marveled at the Eiffel Tower in the City of Lights. When I was eight, I stood in the heart of Piazza San Marco feeding hordes of pigeons, then glided down Venetian waterways on sleek gondolas. At thirteen, I saw the ancient, megalithic structure of Stonehenge and walked along the Great Wall of China, amazed that the thousand-year-old stones were still in place. It was through exploring cultures around the world that I first became interested in language. It began with French, which taught me the importance of pronunciation. As I continued to travel, my fascination with language only grew stronger. I was amazed by how a single phrase, spoken with a different accent or inflection, could completely alter its meaning. In Spain, I learned that the formal "you" (usted) was used to show respect, while in Germany, the informal "you" (du) was used with friends. These nuances sparked a curiosity in me to delve deeper into the world of linguistics.

My experiences with language were not limited to just speaking and listening. I also became fascinated with the written word. In Japan, I was captivated by the intricate characters of Kanji, which seemed to hold secrets and stories of their own. In India, I marveled at the beauty of Devanagari script, which flowed like a river across the page. As I explored these different writing systems, I began to appreciate the complexity and diversity of human communication.

However, it wasn't until I visited Brazil that I truly understood the power of language to bridge cultural divides. I was struck by the warmth and hospitality of the Brazilian people, who welcomed me with open arms despite our language barriers. Through gestures, smiles, and broken Portuguese, we managed to communicate and form connections that transcended words. This experience taught me that language is not just about conveying information, but also about building relationships and fostering understanding.

As I reflect on my travels, I realize that language has been the thread that has woven my experiences together. It has allowed me to connect with people from diverse backgrounds, to appreciate the richness of different cultures, and to gain a deeper understanding of the world around me. My passion for language has also inspired me to pursue a career in international relations, where I hope to use my skills to facilitate cross-cultural communication and foster global cooperation.

In conclusion, my travels have taught me that language is not just a means of communication, but a key to unlocking the secrets of human connection. It has the power to break down barriers, to build bridges, and to foster understanding between people from different cultures and backgrounds. As I look to the future, I am excited to continue exploring the world of language, and to use my skills to make a positive impact on the global community.

This was written for a Common App college application essay prompt that no longer exists, which read: Evaluate a significant experience, risk, achievement, ethical dilemma you have faced and its impact on you. Smeared blood, shredded feathers. Clearly, the bird was dead. But wait, the slight fluctuation of its chest, the slow blinking of its shiny black eyes. No, it was alive. I had been typing an English essay when I heard my cat's loud meows and the flutter of wings. I had turned slightly at the noise and had found the barely breathing bird in front of me. The shock came first. Mind racing, heart beating faster, blood draining from my face. I instinctively reached out my hand to hold it, like a long-lost keepsake from my youth. But then I remembered that birds had life, flesh, blood. Death. Dare I say it out loud? Here, in my own home? Within seconds, my reflexes kicked in. Get over the shock. Gloves, napkins, towels. I hastily gathered the necessary items, my mind racing with the thought of saving this creature's life. The irony was not lost on me - I, a self-proclaimed animal lover, had been so oblivious to the suffering of this bird just moments before. My cat, Mr. Whiskers, sat calmly by my side, seemingly proud of his catch. I shot him a stern glance, but he just blinked innocently.

As I gently wrapped the bird in a towel, I felt a surge of responsibility wash over me. This was no longer just about saving a life; it was about making amends for my initial indifference. I carefully placed the bird in a makeshift nest, constructed from a cardboard box and some old cloth. The bird's labored breathing and faint chirping filled the air, and I knew I had to act fast.

I quickly researched local animal rescue centers and found one that was open 24/7. With the bird securely in its makeshift nest, I rushed out the door, Mr. Whiskers watching me with a curious gaze. The drive was a blur, my mind consumed by thoughts of the bird's fate. Would I be too late? Would they be able to save it?

Upon arriving at the rescue center, I was greeted by a kind-faced volunteer who quickly took the bird from me. She examined it with a practiced eye, her expression a mix of concern and compassion. "We'll do everything we can," she reassured me, as I watched the bird being whisked away to a specialized care unit.

The ride back home was somber, my thoughts reflecting on the experience. I realized that, in that moment, I had been forced to confront my own moral compass. Would I have acted differently if I hadn't been caught off guard? The incident had awakened a sense of empathy within me, a reminder that even in the most mundane of moments, we are faced with choices that can have a profound impact on the world around us.

As I walked back into my house, Mr. Whiskers greeted me with a curious mew. I scooped him up, holding him close, and whispered a silent apology to the bird, now in the care of strangers. The experience had left an indelible mark on me, a reminder to always be mindful of the intricate web of life that surrounds us, and to never underestimate the power of a single, fleeting moment to shape our character.

Bowing down to the porcelain god, I emptied the contents of my stomach. Foaming at the mouth, I was ready to pass out. My body couldn’t stop shaking as I gasped for air, and the room started spinning. Ten minutes prior, I had been eating dinner with my family at a Chinese restaurant, drinking chicken-feet soup. My mom had specifically asked the waitress if there were peanuts in it, because when I was two we found out that I am deathly allergic to them. When the waitress replied no, I went for it. Suddenly I started scratching my neck, feeling the hives that had started to form. I rushed to the restroom to throw up because my throat was itchy and I felt a weight on my chest. I was experiencing anaphylactic shock, which prevented me from taking anything but shallow breaths. As I lay on the cold bathroom floor, my vision began to blur and my body felt like it was shutting down. I could hear my parents' panicked voices outside the door, but they seemed distant, muffled. My mom burst in, her face etched with worry, and quickly assessed the situation. She grabbed her EpiPen, a device that injects epinephrine to counteract the allergic reaction, and administered it to my thigh. The burning sensation was intense, but I knew it was my only hope.

Within minutes, the paramedics arrived, and I was rushed to the hospital. The ambulance ride was a blur, but I remember feeling like I was going to die. My airways were constricting, and every breath was a struggle. The beeping of the machines and the murmurs of the medical staff created a sense of chaos around me.

When we arrived at the hospital, the doctors and nurses sprang into action. They hooked me up to oxygen and IV fluids, and administered more medication to counteract the allergic reaction. I was in and out of consciousness, but I remember the feeling of relief when the doctor told my parents that I was going to be okay.

The incident was a harsh reminder of the severity of my peanut allergy. It's not just a minor inconvenience; it's a matter of life and death. I've learned to be more vigilant, to always carry my EpiPen with me, and to never take food allergies lightly. That night, I came close to losing my life, but it also taught me the importance of being proactive about my health.

In the aftermath of the incident, my family and I made changes to ensure my safety. We started carrying a second EpiPen with us at all times, and we became more meticulous about reading food labels and asking questions about ingredients. We also made sure to educate our friends and family about the severity of my allergy, so they could be better equipped to help in case of an emergency.

The experience was terrifying, but it also taught me a valuable lesson about taking responsibility for my own health. I've learned to be more confident in advocating for myself, and to never take my life for granted. That night, I came face to face with mortality, but it also gave me a newfound appreciation for life.

When I was 16, I lived with the Watkins family in Wichita, Kansas. Mrs. Watkins was the coordinator of the foreign exchange student program I was enrolled in. She had a nine year old son named Cody. I would babysit Cody every day after school for at least two to three hours. We would play Scrabble or he would read to me from Charlotte’s Web or The Ugly Duckling. He would talk a lot about his friends and school life, and I would listen to him and ask him the meanings of certain words. He was my first friend in the New World. My second family was the Martinez family, who were friends of the Watkins’s. The host dad Michael was a high school English teacher and the host mom Jennifer (who had me call her “Jen”) taught elementary school. She had recently delivered a baby, so she was still in the hospital when I moved into their house. The Martinez family did almost everything together. We made pizza together, watched Shrek on their cozy couch together, and went fishing on Sunday together. On rainy days, Michael, Jen and I would sit on the porch and listen to the rain, talking about our dreams and thoughts. Within two months I was calling them mom and dad. After I finished the exchange student program, I had the option of returning to Korea but I decided to stay in America. I wanted to see new places and meet different people. I applied to several colleges and was accepted into a small liberal arts college in the Midwest. It was a big decision, but I knew it was the right one. I wanted to experience the American college life, and I was excited to meet new people and learn from different professors.

During my freshman year, I struggled to adjust to the academic system and language barrier. But with the help of my professors and classmates, I slowly began to find my footing. I joined the international student club and volunteered at a local elementary school, where I helped teach English to young students. It was a rewarding experience, and it reminded me of my time with Cody and the Martinez family.

As I settled into college life, I began to explore different parts of the country. I visited Chicago with my friends, where we took a stroll along Lake Michigan and tried deep-dish pizza for the first time. I went to New York City with my family, where we saw a Broadway show and walked across the Brooklyn Bridge. I even took a road trip to Yellowstone National Park with my roommate, where we marveled at the geysers and hot springs.

But no matter where I went, I always carried the lessons I learned from the Watkins and Martinez families with me. They taught me the importance of family, community, and kindness. They showed me that even in a foreign country, I could find a sense of belonging and home.

After graduating from college, I decided to stay in America and pursue a career in education. I wanted to make a difference in the lives of young students, just like Michael and Jen had made a difference in mine. I earned a master's degree in education and began teaching English at a high school in a diverse neighborhood.

It's been over a decade since I first arrived in Wichita, Kansas, but the memories of my time with the Watkins and Martinez families remain vivid in my mind. They were my first friends in America, and they will always be my second family. I'm grateful for the experience of being an exchange student, which opened my eyes to a new world and introduced me to people who would change my life forever.

Today, I'm proud to say that I'm a naturalized American citizen, and I've built a life here that I love. I still keep in touch with the Watkins and Martinez families, and we meet up whenever I'm in Wichita. Cody is now a grown man with a family of his own, and I'm honored to be his friend. Michael and Jen are still teaching, inspiring new generations of students.

As I look back on my journey, I realize that being an exchange student was just the beginning of my American adventure. It was a chance to discover a new country, a new culture, and a new sense of self. But more than that, it was a chance to form lasting bonds with people who would become my family, my friends, and my community.

I’ve spent most of my life as an anti-vegetable carboholic. For years, processed snack foods ruled the kitchen kingdom of my household and animal products outnumbered plant-based offerings. My transformation began with my mom’s cancer diagnosis. My mom went on a 100% whole food plant-based diet. I fully embraced this new eating philosophy to show my support. Eager to figure out the whole “vegan” thing, the two of us started binge-watching health documentaries such as “What the Health” and “Forks Over Knives”. Those documentaries opened my eyes to the harsh realities of the food industry and the devastating impact of animal agriculture on our health, the environment, and animal welfare. I was shocked to learn about the manipulative tactics used by food manufacturers to keep us hooked on their products, and the ways in which the government and big agriculture collude to prioritize profits over people's health.

As I delved deeper into the world of plant-based eating, I began to notice changes in my own body. My energy levels increased, my skin cleared up, and I felt more mentally alert and focused. I started to experiment with new recipes and ingredients, and discovered a whole new world of flavors and textures that I had been missing out on. My mom and I would spend hours in the kitchen, cooking up a storm and laughing together as we explored this new culinary landscape.

But it wasn't all easy. There were challenges and setbacks along the way. I struggled to give up my beloved cheese and dairy products, and I had to navigate social situations where my new dietary choices were met with skepticism or even ridicule. There were times when I felt like I was losing my identity as a foodie, and that I was sacrificing too much by giving up the foods I loved.

Despite these challenges, I persisted. I started to connect with other like-minded individuals online and in my community, and I found a sense of belonging and support that I had been missing. I began to see that this lifestyle change wasn't just about food, but about taking control of my health, my values, and my impact on the world.

As I continued on this journey, I started to notice the ripple effects of my new lifestyle. My friends and family began to take notice of the changes in me, and they started to ask questions and seek my advice. I started to share my knowledge and experiences with others, and I found that I had a passion for inspiring and empowering others to make positive changes in their own lives.

My transformation also had a profound impact on my relationship with my mom. We had always been close, but this shared experience brought us even closer together. We bonded over our shared passion for plant-based eating, and we supported each other through the ups and downs of this journey. I was grateful to have her by my side as I navigated this new world, and I was inspired by her courage and determination to take control of her health.

Looking back, I realize that my mom's cancer diagnosis was a wake-up call for both of us. It forced us to re-examine our priorities and values, and to make changes that would have a lasting impact on our lives. I'm grateful for that journey, and for the lessons I learned along the way. I'm proud to say that I'm no longer an anti-vegetable carboholic, but a passionate advocate for the power of plant-based eating to transform our lives and our world.

Meditation over a flaxen sunset with a friend and parmesan-topped spaghetti for dinner — “14.” Assignments piling up on my desk as a high fever keeps me sick at home — “3.” Taking a photo excursion through downtown Seattle for a Spanish project — “15.” For the past 700 days and counting, the Happiness Spreadsheet has been my digital collection for documenting numerical, descriptive, and graphical representations of my happiness. Its instructions are simple: Open the Google Sheet, enter a number between 1 and 20 that best represents my level of happiness, and write a short comment describing the day. But the practical aspect of the spreadsheet is only a piece of what it has represented in my life. A “14” etched on November 15, 2018, marked the first Lakeside Cooking on the Stove Club meeting. What had started as a farcical proposition of mine transformed into a playground where high school classmates and I convene every two weeks to prepare a savory afternoon snack for ourselves. A few months later, a “16” scribbled on February 27, 2019, marked the completion of a fence my Spanish class and I constructed for the dusty soccer field at a small Colombian village. Hard-fought days of mixing cement and transporting supplies had paid off for the affectionate community we had immediately come to love. These numerical representations of my happiness have become a tangible manifestation of my personal growth, a reminder of the moments that have shaped me into the person I am today. The spreadsheet has also served as a catalyst for self-reflection, encouraging me to acknowledge and appreciate the beauty in the mundane.

As I scroll through the spreadsheet, I am transported back to memories that would have otherwise been lost in the chaos of everyday life. A "10" on a drizzly April morning reminds me of the impromptu picnic my friends and I had in the school courtyard, laughing and joking as we devoured sandwiches and fruit. A "19" on a warm summer evening brings back the thrill of watching the fireworks display at the Seattle waterfront, the smell of saltwater and smoke lingering in the air.

The Happiness Spreadsheet has also helped me develop a greater sense of empathy and understanding. When I'm feeling down, I can look back at the comments and see that even on my worst days, there were moments of joy to be found. It's a powerful reminder that happiness is not a fixed state, but rather a dynamic and ever-changing entity that can be cultivated and nurtured.

Moreover, the spreadsheet has become a symbol of my commitment to living a life of intention and purpose. In a world that often prioritizes productivity and efficiency, it's easy to get caught up in the hustle and bustle and forget to appreciate the little things. The Happiness Spreadsheet is my rebellion against that, a declaration that happiness and joy are worth fighting for.

As I continue to update the spreadsheet, I am reminded of the power of mindfulness and gratitude. It's easy to get caught up in the negativity and stress that can come with high school life, but the Happiness Spreadsheet encourages me to focus on the positive, to seek out the beauty and joy in every day. And as I look to the future, I know that this habit of reflection and appreciation will serve me well, a reminder to always prioritize my happiness and well-being.

I sit, cradled by the two largest branches of the Newton Pippin Tree, watching the ether. The Green Mountains of Vermont stretch out indefinitely, and from my elevated vantage point, I feel as though we are peers, motionless in solidarity. I’ve lost my corporeal form and instead, while watching invisible currents drive white leviathans across the sky, have drifted up into the epistemological stream; completely alone with my questions, diving for answers. But a few months ago, I would have considered this an utter waste of time. Prior to attending Mountain School, my paradigm was substantially limited; opinions, prejudices, and ideas shaped by the testosterone-rich environment of Landon School. I was herded by result-oriented, fast-paced, technologically-reliant parameters towards psychology and neuroscience (the NIH, a mere 2.11 mile run from my school, is like a beacon on a hill). I was taught that one’s paramount accomplishment should be specialization. But Mountain School, nestled in the heart of Vermont's wilderness, was a far cry from the fast-paced, tech-driven world I was accustomed to. The rustic, off-the-grid campus, surrounded by dense forests and rolling hills, forced me to confront the limitations of my previous paradigm. Without the constant hum of technology, I was compelled to reevaluate my priorities and question the very notion of success.

At first, the adjustment was jarring. I felt lost and disconnected, like a sailor without a compass. The absence of concrete goals and tangible outcomes made me anxious, and I struggled to reconcile my desire for knowledge with the school's emphasis on experiential learning. But as the weeks passed, I began to appreciate the beauty of uncertainty. I discovered that the freedom to explore, to meander, and to question was, in fact, a luxury.

My days at Mountain School were filled with moments of epiphany, like the one I experienced beneath the Newton Pippin Tree. As I sat, suspended between the branches, I realized that the pursuit of knowledge was not a linear journey, but a labyrinthine exploration of the human experience. The trees, the mountains, and the sky became my teachers, imparting lessons on the interconnectedness of all things.

The more I immersed myself in the natural world, the more I began to see the world in a different light. I started to question the notion that success was synonymous with specialization. I wondered if the relentless pursuit of expertise was not, in fact, a form of intellectual myopia. Was it not possible that the most profound insights lay at the intersections, where disciplines converged and merged?

As I delved deeper into the world of ideas, I discovered a new appreciation for the humanities. I found solace in the words of poets and philosophers, who spoke to the complexities and mysteries of human existence. I began to see that the pursuit of knowledge was not merely about accumulating facts, but about cultivating wisdom, empathy, and understanding.

My time at Mountain School was a journey of self-discovery, a process of shedding the skin of my old self and emerging anew. It was a reminder that education is not merely about the acquisition of knowledge, but about the cultivation of a curious, open, and receptive mind. As I sit beneath the Newton Pippin Tree, watching the clouds drift lazily across the sky, I am reminded that the greatest accomplishment is not specialization, but the ability to see the world with fresh eyes, to question, and to wonder.

Before I came to America, I drank Puer Tea with my father every morning in my bedroom, sitting cross-legged on Suzhou-silk mats beside a view of the Lakeside reservoir. Beside a dark end table, we picked up teacups as the mild aroma greeted our noses. As we faced the French window, my father would share the news he read in China Daily: the Syrian civil war, climate change, and gender equality in Hollywood. Most of the time, I only listened. Those morning rituals were a sacred part of my childhood, a time when the world seemed simpler and more innocent. My father's voice would rise and fall as he discussed the news, his tone measured and thoughtful. I would nod along, pretending to understand the complexities of global politics, but in reality, I was more fascinated by the way the sunlight danced through the French window, casting intricate patterns on the floor.

As I grew older, our morning conversations began to shift. My father would ask me about my day, my interests, and my dreams. I would share with him my passion for literature, my love for Chinese poetry, and my aspirations to become a writer. He would listen intently, his eyes sparkling with pride, and offer words of encouragement. Those moments were precious to me, a time when I felt seen and heard by the person I admired most in the world.

But life had other plans. I grew up, and my family moved to America. The Lakeside reservoir was replaced by the towering skyscrapers of New York City. The Suzhou-silk mats were swapped for a small, cluttered apartment in Queens. And the morning rituals, once so sacred, began to fade away.

At first, I tried to hold on to the tradition. I would wake up early, brew a pot of Puer Tea, and sit alone in my small bedroom, staring out the window at the unfamiliar cityscape. But it wasn't the same. The news was different, the language was different, and the world seemed to be spinning at a frantic pace. I felt lost and disconnected, a small boat adrift in a stormy sea.

As the days turned into weeks, and the weeks into months, I began to lose touch with my father. We would talk on the phone, but the conversations were stilted and awkward. He would ask me about my job, my apartment, and my life in America, but I struggled to find the words to describe the sense of dislocation and disorientation that had taken over my life.

I felt like I was living in two worlds, one foot in China and the other in America. I was torn between the comfort and familiarity of my childhood and the uncertainty and excitement of my new life. I was struggling to find my place in this new world, to find my voice and my identity.

But as I sat alone in my bedroom, sipping my Puer Tea and staring out the window, I began to realize that my father's lessons had stayed with me. He had taught me to be curious, to be open-minded, and to be brave. He had taught me to face the world with a sense of wonder and a sense of responsibility.

And so, I began to rebuild my life, to find my footing in this new world. I started writing again, pouring my thoughts and feelings onto the page. I started exploring the city, discovering new neighborhoods and new cultures. And I started to reconnect with my father, to find common ground in our shared experiences and our shared values.

As I look back on those morning rituals, I realize that they were more than just a pleasant memory. They were a foundation, a foundation upon which I could build my life. They were a reminder that even in the darkest of times, there is always hope, always a chance to start anew. And they were a testament to the power of love and family, a reminder that no matter where life takes us, we are always connected, always bound together by the threads of our shared humanity.

I am a dancer. It’s something I’ve only learned recently, but it’s my reality. My story is not one of the typical dancer: I was not the student who couldn’t sit still or pay attention in class, only to find focus and expression through movement. That just isn’t my story. Instead, my journey as a dancer began much later in life, when I was already an adult. I had always been interested in dance, but I never thought I was good enough or had the right body type to pursue it seriously. I was always the observer, watching in awe as dancers glided effortlessly across the stage, their movements seemingly choreographed to perfection.

But something shifted inside of me when I turned 30. Maybe it was the realization that life is short, and I shouldn't let fear hold me back from trying something I truly loved. Maybe it was the desire to challenge myself and push beyond my comfort zone. Whatever the reason, I finally gathered the courage to sign up for a dance class at a local studio.

At first, it was intimidating. I felt like I was the only beginner in a sea of seasoned dancers. My body was stiff, my coordination was off, and I struggled to remember even the simplest of steps. But as I continued to attend class, something remarkable happened. I began to feel a sense of freedom and release that I had never experienced before.

Dancing allowed me to tap into a part of myself that I never knew existed. It was as if my body had been waiting for this moment, this chance to express itself in a way that was both physical and emotional. I felt like I was unlocking a deep well of creativity and passion that had been hidden beneath the surface.

As I continued to dance, I began to notice changes in other areas of my life as well. I felt more confident, more self-assured. I carried myself with a newfound sense of pride and poise. I started to see the world in a different light, as if everything was infused with a sense of rhythm and movement.

Of course, there are still days when I feel like I'm not good enough, when I doubt my abilities and wonder why I'm even trying. But those moments are fleeting, because I know that dancing is not just about the steps or the technique – it's about the journey, the process of self-discovery and growth.

As I look back on my journey as a dancer, I realize that it's not about being a certain type or fitting into a particular mold. It's about embracing my uniqueness, my quirks, and my imperfections. It's about finding my own rhythm, my own style, and my own voice.

And so, I'll continue to dance, to move, to express myself in ways that feel authentic and true. I'll continue to push beyond my limits, to challenge myself, and to grow. Because in the end, that's what being a dancer is all about – embracing the beauty of imperfection, and finding freedom in the movement.

Winter is coming. And as the chilly season approaches, my high school will soon be invaded by smoothing…abominable. Lovesick teenagers armed with cheesy posters and grocery store flowers. Because at my school, winter is the harbinger of the Winter Formal Dance. a ritual that brings out the most cringe-worthy displays of affection and awkwardness from my fellow students. It's as if the cold weather has somehow awakened a deep-seated desire in them to proclaim their undying love to the world, or at least to their significant other.

As the days leading up to the dance approach, the hallways of my school transform into a scene from a bad rom-com. Couples cling to each other, gazing lovingly into each other's eyes, completely oblivious to the fact that they're blocking the lockers and causing a human traffic jam. The sound of giggling and whispers of "I love you, babe" fills the air, making me want to roll my eyes so hard they get stuck that way.

The posters, oh the posters. They're the worst. Giant, glittery signs that scream "Will you go to Winter Formal with me?" in Comic Sans font, accompanied by a drawing of a heart or a cartoon character. It's like they're trying to outdo each other in a competition of who can be the most creative and over-the-top. Newsflash: it's just a dance, people. Not a marriage proposal.

And then there are the flowers. Oh, the flowers. They're always the final nail in the coffin of my sanity. Grocery store bouquets of wilted roses and baby's breath, hastily purchased by desperate suitors trying to impress their dates. They're thrust into the hands of unsuspecting girls, who coo and squeal with delight, completely unaware of the fact that they're holding a symbol of their boyfriend's laziness.

But despite all the chaos and cheesiness, I have to admit that there's something endearing about Winter Formal. Maybe it's the way the school is transformed into a winter wonderland, complete with twinkling lights and fake snowflakes. Or maybe it's the excitement and anticipation that builds up in the days leading up to the dance.

As I watch my friends and classmates prepare for the big night, I can't help but feel a pang of nostalgia. Winter Formal may be a bit ridiculous, but it's also a rite of passage, a chance for us to let loose and have fun before the stresses of college applications and final exams take over.

So, I'll put up with the posters and the flowers, the lovesick gazes and the awkward slow dances. Because in the end, Winter Formal is a reminder that even in the midst of chaos and cringe-worthiness, there's still room for a little bit of magic and romance.

I was immensely disappointed when I didn’t hear my name as the winners were being announced. A few seconds before, I was so excited that it might have seemed as if I was waiting to win the Nobel Prize, instead of an award for my project in mathematics at the Scientific and Research Council of Turkey National Projects Competition. Throughout the 4 days of the Project Fair, I presented my project to over 100 visitors. including judges, teachers, and students from various schools. I had confidently explained the concept, methodology, and results of my project, answering numerous questions and receiving positive feedback from many of them. Therefore, when the winner's name was announced, and it wasn't mine, I felt a pang of disappointment and disillusionment.

As I walked out of the auditorium, I couldn't help but wonder what had gone wrong. Had my project not been good enough? Had I not presented it well enough? These questions swirled in my mind, making me question my abilities and the effort I had put into my project. I felt like I had let myself and my family down.

But as I began to reflect on the experience, I realized that the true value of participating in the competition lay not in winning, but in the journey itself. I had spent countless hours researching, experimenting, and refining my project, and in the process, I had learned so much about mathematics, critical thinking, and problem-solving. I had also developed important skills such as communication, time management, and perseverance.

Moreover, the Project Fair had provided me with an opportunity to meet and interact with like-minded individuals who shared my passion for science and mathematics. We had exchanged ideas, discussed our projects, and learned from each other's experiences. These interactions had broadened my perspective and inspired me to continue pursuing my interests in mathematics.

As I looked back on the four days of the Project Fair, I realized that I had gained so much more than a prize or recognition. I had gained confidence in my abilities, a sense of accomplishment, and a deeper understanding of the importance of perseverance and hard work. I had also learned to appreciate the value of feedback and constructive criticism, which had helped me to refine my project and improve my presentation skills.

In the days that followed, I received numerous messages of encouragement and support from my teachers, family, and friends. They reminded me that winning was not everything and that the true measure of success lay in the effort and dedication I had put into my project. They encouraged me to continue pursuing my passions and to use this experience as a stepping stone for future success.

As I reflect on this experience, I am reminded of the importance of resilience and perseverance. Life is full of setbacks and disappointments, but it is how we respond to them that matters. We can choose to let them discourage us, or we can use them as opportunities to learn and grow. I am grateful for the experience of participating in the Scientific and Research Council of Turkey National Projects Competition, and I am proud of myself for having the courage to take risks and pursue my dreams, even in the face of disappointment.

In the end, I realized that winning was not the only measure of success. Success lies in the journey, the learning, and the growth that we experience along the way. It lies in the relationships we build, the skills we develop, and the confidence we gain. And it is these things that will stay with me long after the competition is over, inspiring me to continue pursuing my passions and striving for excellence in all that I do.

Growing up with a stutter was difficult. My thoughts were always fully formed, but the words would get stuck. The harder I tried to force them out, the more they would jam up, like train cars going off a track. Sometimes kids would laugh or make fun of my stutter, but mostly they just ignored me. They had better things to do than wait to hear my ideas, so they assumed I had none worth hearing. As I grew older, the frustration and embarrassment of having a stutter only intensified. I would avoid speaking up in class, fearing that my classmates would giggle or whisper to each other. I would hesitate to order food at a restaurant, worried that the cashier would misunderstand me or think I was stupid. Even simple conversations with my family became a source of anxiety, as I struggled to articulate my thoughts and feelings.

But the most painful part of having a stutter was the feeling of being silenced. It was as if my stutter had taken away my voice, my ability to express myself and be heard. I felt like I was living in a world where everyone else had a megaphone, while I was stuck with a whisper. I longed to be able to speak freely, to be able to share my thoughts and ideas without fear of ridicule or judgment.

Despite the challenges, I was determined to overcome my stutter. I began to see a speech therapist, who taught me techniques to slow down my speech and relax my muscles. I practiced every day, repeating words and phrases in front of the mirror, trying to smooth out the rough edges of my speech. It was hard work, but slowly, I began to see progress.

One of the most significant breakthroughs came when I discovered the power of writing.
